item.title: China | Airlines dispute US proposal to ban flights over Russia
item.description: China's main state-owned airlines contested a United States proposal to ban flights that cross Russian airspace on routes between the two countries, citing an impact on passengers and a competitive imbalance. Air China, China Eastern and China Southern are among six Chinese carriers that have filed complaints with the US Department of Transportation against the order, proposed last week, which seeks to ban flights over Russia by Chinese carriers. In its response, China Eastern claimed that the measure “harms the public interest” and “creates inconvenience for travelers” from China and the US, stressing that increased flight times would translate into higher costs and more expensive fares. China Southern warned that the ban would negatively affect thousands of passengers, while Air China estimated that at least 4,400 travelers would be affected if the restriction came into force during the Thanksgiving (November 27) and Christmas season. Russian airspace was closed to North American airlines and most European carriers in 2022 following the imposition of Western sanctions over Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Chinese flights, however, continue to have access, giving them, according to Washington, an unfair advantage over their US competitors. Chinese diplomacy spokesman Guo Jiakun had already reacted last week, considering that the proposal represents a “punishment” for passengers from all over the world. According to David Yu, an aviation sector expert at New York University in Shanghai, the impossibility of flying over Russia has increased the duration of some US-China routes by two to three hours, putting pressure on the operational costs and profitability of North American companies. “Historically, the China-US route has been highly profitable for both sides,” Yu said. “If Chinese carriers can fly over Russia, their costs are lower,” he noted.

item.title: Sam Hou Fai talks about “new phase” of the principle of one country, two systems
item.description: The Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, said yesterday that “Macau has entered the new phase of applying the principle of one country, two systems” and that it is struggling “with profound and complex changes in the internal and external environment”, in addition to that the world finds itself “in a new period of turbulence and change”. Speaking at an event celebrating the 105th anniversary of the Macau Red Cross Foundation, Sam Hou Fai recalled that “compatriots need more humanistic care and spiritual comfort”, and therefore hopes that the Red Cross “will continue to pay attention and support to the development of the Macao SAR and the Government's actions”. The governor defended that this century-old organization must be attentive to “government plans and demands for the high-quality development of Macau in the new journey”, with the hope that there will be reinforced cooperation with the Chinese Red Cross Society. Long life The Chief Executive highlighted that the Macau Red Cross has been “rooted” in the territory since 1920, and, in addition to “serving Macau, it also closely monitors and supports humanitarian services and activities of public interest in Mainland China and internationally”. The highest ruler of the MSAR did not forget the moment of transition, when the “Red Cross of Macau officially became the Delegation with a high degree of autonomy of the Red Cross Society of China, being a witness, participant and contributor to the successful application of the principle of one country, two systems with Macau characteristics”. Still on governance, Sam Hou Fai promised to “build a Macau based on the rule of law, dynamic, cultural and happy”, continuing with the “focus on supporting the most vulnerable layers” and assuming “the reinforcement of the feeling of fulfillment, happiness and security of all Macau residents as the starting point and basis of government action”. It was also guaranteed that the Executive “will fully support the Macau Red Cross in the planning and development of activities”.

item.title: Tourism | Andy Wu calls for greater disclosure of intangible heritage
item.description: Andy Wu, president of the Macau Tourism Industry Association, argues that intangible cultural heritage should be more widely publicized to tourists, at a time when the Cultural Institute has just announced 12 new classifications, namely the making of cream puffs and traditional almond cookies, traditional Chinese wedding cakes and the making of jook-sing dough. According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the association leader understands that cultural tourism offers can include intangible cultural heritage, providing extraordinary experiences to tourists, namely the holding of custard tart and almond biscuit workshops, among others. This type of event would be organized between the sector, education linked to tourism and personalities from society, so that visitors would have more information about the production process. Andy Wu hopes that the Government will provide more support as he understands that these initiatives can help to overcome the lack of spaces for tourists to have these types of experiences. Few stores still make traditional Chinese wedding cakes.

item.title: FRC | Debate on criminal issues in the PLP takes place today
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) presents today, starting at 6:30 pm, a debate on “Paradigmatic Penal Issues in Portuguese-Speaking Countries”, which includes four thematic lectures. This is an initiative that is part of the “Cycle of Reflections at Dusk”, moderated by Leonor Esteves, from Universidade Lusíada do Porto. Today, the sessions “Nullum crimen sine lege and article 7 (Custom) of the Constitution of the Republic of Angola” are taking place, led by professor Luzia Bebiana de Almeida Sebastião, from the Faculty of Law of the Agostinho Neto University, Angola; and the conversation “Criminal Law and Democracy: the recent experience of the Brazilian case” by professor Fernando Andrade Fernandes, from the Department of Public Law of the Faculty of Human and Social Sciences of the Universidade Estadual Paulista, UNESP, Brazil. Another session is entitled “The material legitimacy of the crime of association in Mozambican law” by legal advisor and professor Elysa Vieira, from the Constitutional Council and Eduardo Mondlane University, Mozambique; and also the “Inviolability of communications and seizure of electronic mail” by professor Maria João Antunes, from the Faculty of Law of the University of Coimbra. The presence in the territory of this group of guest speakers is part of the 15th International Law Conference, this year dedicated to “Macau Legal Reforms in the Global Context: Studies on the Penal Code and the Macau Criminal Procedure Code”, organized by the Legal Studies Center of the Faculty of Law of the University of Macau, which takes place today and tomorrow and has the support of the FRC.

item.title: Taiwan | Residents seduced people into scams
item.description:
This Monday, six residents were arrested on suspicion of being linked to a criminal group in Taiwan associated with fraud, and who had recruited nine residents to extort money from victims. The investigation began in September last year, and the Judicial Police is still investigating the amounts involved
This Monday, the Judiciary Police arrested six Macau residents allegedly involved with a Taiwanese criminal group associated with fraud. According to the Ou Mun newspaper, the case began when the Judiciary Police (PJ) began an investigation after receiving requests for help from family members of nine missing Macau residents. Authorities later realized that these nine residents had been detained by Taiwan police and sentenced to prison terms of three to eight months for committing the crime of fraud. The role of these residents was to receive and deliver the extorted money to fraud victims, with four of these residents later returning to Macau after serving their sentence. It is estimated that the nine residents received thousands to tens of thousands of renminbi in payment for these roles. The Macau PJ then realized that the nine residents tried in Taiwan had been recruited by the six arrested on Monday, with promises of high salaries to carry out illegal activities in the former Formosa. Amounts to be calculated The PJ also realized that two of the six detainees are the main perpetrators of the criminal group in Taiwan, having received illegal payments of 1 to 3 percent for each amount of fraud extorted by the nine residents detained in Taiwan. However, the PJ said it needed to investigate the specific amounts received by these two main perpetrators of the crime, as well as the illegal remuneration received by the other suspects. The case was forwarded to the Public Prosecutor's Office for further investigation, as there are suspicions of the crime of criminal association.

item.title: Airport | Expansion guarantees capacity for 13 million visitors
item.description:
Even before the increase in passenger capacity, the airport will receive a larger parking area for aircraft, with the number of spaces increasing to 56 compared to the current 36
By the end of 2030, Macau International Airport will have the capacity to receive 13 million passengers per year. The figures were presented by a representative of the Civil Aviation Authority (AACM), at the most recent meeting of the Islands' Community Services Advisory Council, which took place on Monday. The summary of the meeting was given to the newspaper Ou Mun by counselors Li Yongjian and Ieong Weng Kuong, who cited the responses from the AACM meeting. According to the explanations mentioned, expansion works are underway, after having started in April. The new parking area is expected to be completed in 2028, which will increase aircraft parking spaces from the current 36 to 56 spaces, an increase of 55.6 percent. At the same time, it was indicated that estimates indicate that the expansion works will be fully completed in 2030, within around five years, and that at that time the airport will have the capacity to handle another two million travelers, compared to the current capacity of 11 million per year. Last year, the airport received 7.6 million travelers, two million fewer than the record number of passengers reached in 2019, even before the pandemic, when there were 9.6 million travelers using the infrastructure. However, the number appears to show a further reduction. Between January and October this year, around 5.5 million passengers were recorded. Last year, in the first ten months, there were 5.7 million passengers. Largest area With ongoing work, the total area of ​​the airport will be increased to 325 hectares, compared to the current 177 hectares. At the meeting, the councilors also addressed other issues related to the airport, such as issues related to security and passenger transport between the boarding pier and the planes. In this sense, counselors were assured that given the current limitations on the number of boarding lanes available, that passenger transportation between the boarding pier and the aircraft will continue to be done via buses. This will also be the method used for future aircraft parking spaces. During the meeting, according to Li Yongjian and Ieong Weng Kuong, there were also advisors calling for the development of more complementary facilities at the airport, as well as paying special attention to ensuring that the transport center is prepared to deal with the flow of passengers that occurs during large-scale events, such as the recent NBA pre-season games in Macau.

item.title: Hainan | Taking advantage of Macau to import Portuguese-speaking products
item.description:
During a visit to Forum Macau, governor Liu Xiaoming said he wanted to create synergies with the Macao SAR so that Portuguese-speaking products can enter the interior
The leader of the island of Hainan stated yesterday that he wants to help Portuguese-speaking products enter the Chinese market, defending synergies with Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries. Governor Liu Xiaoming pointed out as a goal “the construction of Hainan as a hub for the entry of products from Portuguese-speaking countries into the interior of China”. Liu was speaking during a visit to the facilities of the Forum for Economic and Trade Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries, known as the Macau Forum. According to Forum Macau, the leader of Hainan asked the organization for support, also to help companies on the island “to deepen their knowledge of market rules and investment environments in Portuguese-speaking nations”. According to a statement, Liu defended the bet on “synergistic development between Hainan, Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries” and recalled that the island will become a free port before the end of the year. From December 18, imported products that are processed in Hainan – with an added value of at least 30 percent – ​​can enter mainland China without paying customs duties. Bet on the advantages On Monday, even before going to Forum Macau, Liu Xiaoming had a meeting with Sam Hou Fai. According to a statement from the Macau Government, Sam argued that there may be “complementarity of advantages” between the free port of Hainan and the Deep Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau. This special economic zone, jointly managed by Guangdong province and Macau, was launched by Beijing and 2021 and covers around 106 square kilometers on Mountain Island, adjacent to Macau. China established Macau as a platform for strengthening economic and trade cooperation with Portuguese-speaking countries in 2003 and, in that same year, created the Macau Forum. The organization includes, in addition to China, the nine Portuguese-speaking countries: Angola, Brazil, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Portugal, São Tomé and Príncipe, Timor-Leste and, since 2022, Equatorial Guinea. Exports from Portuguese-speaking countries to China fell 11.3 percent to $86.6 billion in the first eight months of the year, according to official data.

item.title: AL | Deputies take office this morning
item.description: The deputies of the Legislative Assembly take office this morning for the beginning of the VIII Legislature. The oath is scheduled for 11 am, in the meeting room of the Service Platform Complex for Commercial Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries. In the afternoon, at 3pm, the first session of the Plenary of the Legislative Assembly is scheduled, which will serve to elect the future president, vice-president, first secretary and second secretary. After the meeting, there will be another oath session, on the same day, at 4 pm, and the AL president will be sworn in. The session also takes place at the Service Platform Complex for Commercial Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries. Following the government reshuffle, Wong Sio Chak and Chan Tsz King will hold the oath and inauguration ceremony this morning, at 10am, at the Government headquarters. Wong Sio Chak will take on the role of Secretary for Administration and Justice, while Chan Tsz King will be the new Secretary for Security. In the 10 am session, the first of three that will take place tomorrow, the oath ceremony and inauguration of Tong Hio Fong as Prosecutor of the Macao SAR and the new members of the Executive Council are also scheduled. The ceremony is not open to the public. AMCM | Chan Kuan I appointed to Board of Directors Chan Kuan I was appointed member of the Board of Directors of the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM). The measure comes into force next Monday, according to an order from Sam Hou Fai, published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. With a degree in Commerce (Accounting) from Monash University in Australia and a master's degree in Public Administration taught by Peking University and the Chinese Academy of Governance, Chan has been part of the AMCM staff since August 2001, although with a break between 2006 and 2009, when she worked in the Financial Information Office. After returning to AMCM, the new member performed the functions of technician, deputy director and director of the Insurance Supervision Department. DSSCU | Chan Hoi Ieng appointed deputy director Raymond Tam appointed Chan Hoi Ieng, one of his office advisors, as deputy director of the Land and Urban Construction Services Directorate (DSSCU). The appointment was revealed yesterday through the Official Bulletin. Chan Hoi Ieng has a degree in Engineering from Tsinghua University and a Master's degree in Public Administration from Peking University. At a professional level, she was a senior technician between December 1999 and November 2016 at the then Institute for Civic and Municipal Affairs. Between 2016 and 2022, she performed the same type of functions in the Customs Services, until December of last year, when she was promoted to advisor. Also in December last year, she was appointed advisor to the Office of the Secretary for Transport and Public Works. She is now chosen as deputy director of DSSCU.

item.title: DSAT | Chiang Ngoc Vai takes over as director
item.description:
After almost 20 years at the head of the department responsible for traffic, Chiang was promoted to the top of the hierarchy. Since July, he has performed his duties as a substitute after Lam Hin San's departure
After three months as deputy director of the Directorate of Traffic Affairs Services (DSAT), Chiang Ngoc Vai took over the portfolio in his own capacity yesterday. The information was revealed through an order published in the Official Bulletin, signed by Raymond Tam, Secretary for Transport and Public Works. In addition to three months as deputy director, Chiang Ngoc Vai has a career spanning almost 20 years at DSAT, a service he joined for the first time in 2008, soon to assume the role of deputy director. From that time, until July of this year, Chiang remained as deputy director and it was in this capacity in recent months that he assumed the role of director, after the departure of his predecessor, Lam Hin San. The promotion confirmed yesterday, and the removal of Lam Hin San, also show Raymond Tam's break with the past, given that Chiang's predecessor had been appointed by the previous Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raimundo do Rosário, deserving his trust for around 10 years. The order does not indicate any particular reasons for the appointment, other than the pro-forma indicating that Chiang Ngoc Vai “has professional competence and aptitude for the role” and the nominee's CV. As with service commission appointments, the secretary's choice is valid for a period of one year. From engineering In academic terms, the order indicates that Chiang Ngoc has two degrees in Civil Engineering and Science (Cadastral Topography and Spatial Planning). The teaching institutions for the degrees are not mentioned. On a professional level, the director of DSAT has a long history in Public Administration, spanning more than 30 years. Chiang joined the Directorate of Land, Public Works and Transport Services in October 1990, working as a technician. In March 1992, he was promoted within the same department, to assume the role of head of sector. Even before the transfer, in 1995, Chiang Ngoc Vai was once again promoted internally to take on the role of senior technician and also Head of Department. He remained in these roles until 2008, for another 13 years, when he was appointed to DSAT.

item.title: Literature | “In Memory” is the new book from publisher Mandarina
item.description: The new editorial project of Mandarina, a publisher dedicated to children's literature, will be launched on October 25th. “In Memória” is part of the collection “Pequenos Exploradores de Macau” which addresses the universes of Macau’s memory and heritage through the writing of Catarina Mesquita Publisher Mandarina has teamed up with a series of partners, including the International Institute of Macau (IIM), to launch a new book for children that explores the worlds of heritage and the importance of preserving it and remembering a territory in permanent mutation. “Na Memória”, written by Catarina Mesquita and with illustrations by Fernando Chan, brings back the adventures of the characters Júlia and Pou, she talking to her father; him talking to his grandmother. Ao HM, Catarina Mesquita desvenda as razões pela escolha do tema memória para este novo livro, o terceiro integrado na colecção “Pequenos Exploradores de Macau”, que inclui os títulos “Na Rua” e “Em Casa”. "The dynamics are the same [in relation to the previous books]: it is a book with two stories and two characters, but the ending is common. I decided on memory not only because of the importance it has in our lives, but to convey to children the idea that everything we experience is very important and is part of our construction, especially children who live in Macau, as they see things evolving that should stay within them." The co-edition with the IIM is due to the fact that it is celebrating 25 years since the inscription of the historic center of Macau as a heritage site classified by UNESCO. "Memory is part of this heritage, of its preservation. As our books have always highlighted places, festivities and situations in Macau, we thought we could continue the collection and associate ourselves with this important landmark." Three books, six stories “In Memória” is a bilingual book, in Portuguese and traditional Chinese, also having an interactive part with stickers, with words in both languages ​​and in Patuá, a Macanese dialect that is practically on the verge of extinction. "We decided to include the patuá because of this connection with memory and heritage. So the book has two pages of stickers in which readers observe the scenery and in which more importance is given to the illustration", explained Catarina Mesquita. "The way I portrayed memory is always associated with the children's vision and the curious questions they ask. We have Júlia interacting with her father and Pou with his grandmother about the experiences they have over the course of a year, which is the time period of the story. They ask questions and there are things that register in their heads." The author of the book describes a part of the story in which Júlia climbs the Macau Tower with her father and he explains to her the future of Macau, built with the new city of Hengqin. Júlia is an eight-year-old girl who is seeing a new city being born, while “Pou's grandmother is 80 years old and has been in Macau for a long time, so she has memories of a Macau that her grandson doesn't know”. “There is this transition between the past, present and future to make children think a little, that things change and to make them realize that there are things that, in their lives in Macau, really change, like this case of looking around and seeing a mega-city growing”, said the founder of Mandarina. Having existed for almost six years in the small publishing market of Macau, Catarina Mesquita talks about what still needs to be done so that greater emphasis is placed on children's literature. "We know the market we have, which is not very significant. We cannot reach all the children in Macau and we feel that there is a lack of support that is not just financial. Although there are [financial, project support] funds, much greater support is needed in terms of values. In recent years the Macau Government has promoted children's literature and reading, but there is no situation in which publishers work together to develop children's literature in Macau", he laments. Catarina Mesquita understands that this type of literature is still seen as not having “great priority, especially that which is made for leisure and not that which is given in schools”. "There is little investment in this reading for pleasure and there needs to be greater investment, in addition to taking a serious look at this type of children's literature, as it is essential for the future. It is necessary to give children this basis, so that they look at the book as a companion object", he concluded. The presentation of the book will take place on the 25th as part of the “Exhibition of Illustrated Books in Chinese and Portuguese”, at the Carmo Auditorium, in Taipa, starting at 6:30 pm.

item.title: Apple | Tim Cook will reinforce presence and cooperation with China
item.description: Apple's executive president, Tim Cook, yesterday assured the Chinese Minister of Industry and Information Technology that the North American technology company will reinforce investment and deepen cooperation with China, aiming for “mutually beneficial” development. During the meeting in Beijing, the two sides discussed the situation of the US company in the country and possible areas of collaboration in the electronics and information technology sectors, according to a statement from the Chinese ministry. Minister Li Lecheng highlighted that China has a “huge market” and a complete industrial system, which represents “high potential for investment and consumption”. The government official reiterated that the country will continue to promote “high-level opening” to the outside world and promote “smart industrialization” and “industrial intelligence”, creating an environment conducive to foreign investment, including that of Apple. The minister also expressed the desire for Apple to deepen its presence in the Chinese market, collaborating with local companies in innovation, development and throughout the supply chain, in addition to participating “actively in the new industrialization process” in the country. Present in China for two decades, Apple maintains a vast network of suppliers and assembly partners in the country, where a significant part of its global production continues to be concentrated, despite having begun to diversify part of its manufacturing to other Asian countries in recent years. On Monday, Cook announced that the new iPhone Air will be launched in mainland China on October 22, coinciding with the entry into force of the eSIM service – electronic cards – offered by the three main Chinese operators. The so-called “Greater China” – which includes mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan – represents Apple's third largest market, behind only the Americas and Europe.

item.title: Economy | Stability forecast in the fourth quarter
item.description: The Macau Economic Association has just released the latest Prosperity Index, which forecasts a stable economy until December. According to a statement from the association, despite considering the performances of the gaming and tourism sectors during Golden Week to be excellent, there are economic areas that still perform weaker, such as consumption, credit and confidence in local investments. For this reason, the association assigned, on a scale of 0 to 10, 6.2 points, 6 points and 6.1 points, respectively, for the months of October, November and December with regard to the economic situation, which means a level of stability. Furthermore, the association highlighted that data related to tourism and gaming in the third quarter were strong, predicting positive growth in Gross Domestic Product of around 7 percent in the third quarter. Foreign Exchange Reserves | Monthly increase of 1.6% In September, the Macao SAR's foreign exchange reserves increased by 1.6 percent to 239.2 billion patacas, compared to the adjusted amounts in August. The data was released yesterday by the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM), through a press release. In August, foreign exchange reserves reached 235.4 billion patacas. The effective exchange rate of the pataca, weighted by its trade shares, was 100.8 in September 2025, which represented a drop of 0.06 points in monthly terms and an annual reduction of 1.60 points. In view of this variation, AMCM reported that globally “the pataca fell against the currencies of Macau’s main trading partners”.

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: Cuts in humanitarian aid funding could expose up to 13.7 million people to extreme hunger around the world, the World Food Program (WFP) warned yesterday. “The humanitarian aid system is under severe pressure as partners withdraw from frontline areas, creating a void,” the Rome-based agency said in a new report titled “A lifebuoy in danger.” The UN agency said that six of its operations – in Afghanistan, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Haiti, Somalia, South Sudan and Sudan – are “facing major disruptions, which will only worsen”. WFP warned that its financing “has never been so challenging”, anticipating “a 40 percent drop” in 2025, “which will translate into a projected budget of US$6.4 billion, compared to US$10 billion in 2024”. The report does not name any countries, but points to a study published in the medical journal The Lancet, which found that 14 million additional deaths worldwide from disease, nutritional deficiencies and maternal and perinatal conditions could occur by 2030 as a result of cuts in US humanitarian aid alone. Returns and records Since US President Donald Trump's return to the White House, Washington has announced massive cuts in its foreign aid, dealing a huge blow to humanitarian operations around the world. "Program coverage has been significantly reduced and rations cut. Vital assistance to families in food disaster situations [Phase 5 of the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification/IPC] is threatened, while preparedness for future impacts has significantly decreased," warns WFP. Globally, “WFP estimates that its funding gaps could push 10.5 to 13.7 million people currently in acute food insecurity (IPC Phase 3) into a humanitarian emergency (IPC Phase 4),” the organization added. The UN agency said global hunger has now reached record levels, with 319 million people facing acute food insecurity — including 44 million at emergency levels.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Sun Yang, who lived in the time of Spring and Autumn (771-476 BC) because he was considered an exemplary judge in choosing a good horse, earned the honorific title of Bole from a king, «the happy eldest» and his praised ability to choose gave rise to the popular saying that says that «good horses capable of running a thousand li in a day (qianlima) are many, a Bole is rare». This would soon be adopted as a metaphor for all areas where it was necessary or vital to know how to choose talent, especially hidden talent such as in the selection of government employees. But this skill, specifically referring to horses, was especially valued in the time of the dynasty founded by the Mongol knights of the Yuan. The most notable painters of that time, such as Zhao Mengfu, portrayed several of the dynasty's most famous horses. And a court painter around the year 1342 showed, with indifference, a horse offered to the emperor, as was customary in the tax system with foreign countries, but which would remain as unexpected visual proof of the stay in the territory of a mission headed by the Florentine Franciscan Giovanni de Marignolli (c. 1290- 1358) who had arrived in Khanbaliq (present-day Beijing) as legate of the Pope in 1339-40, following the unprecedented reception of Giovanni da Montecorvino OFM (1247-1328) at the Yuan court, which even allowed him to build churches in the streets of the capital. This horizontal scroll made only in ink, a copy of which was probably made in the Ming dynasty and is in the Palace Museum in Beijing, is attributed to the court painter Zhou Lang, who created in another painting an unforgettable portrait of a poet whose memory is largely due to the testimony of a contemporary capable of recognizing her unique talent. Zhou Lang made the portrait of Du Qiuniang, «the Autumn Maiden» (791-835), with an ancient flute in his hands in a figurative style respecting the «spirit of the ancients» as Zhao Mengfu wanted, and on the model of the ladies of the Tang dynasty. From the portrait in this horizontal scroll (ink and color on silk, 32.3 x 285 cm in the Palace Museum in Beijing) was an exhortation to a prince, which would last and can be translated as: «I ask you, Lord: do not be dazzled / by the lives of those who carry gold / in the seams of their dresses/ My advice, Lord, / is that your green years / be well lived. / Pick the flowers when they bloom, / not when they are already falling, / Don’t wait until there are no longer / flowers on the broken branches.” It is known about the author that she was educated in the arts of dance and music and impressed a general who was defeated by an emperor and took her to his court and, following political conflicts, returned to her native Nanking. And it was there that, aged and impoverished, the poet Du Mu (803-52) found her, who wrote a poem about her and her brief biography.

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description: The philosophical questions that will arise throughout this text are based on concrete data, they are not inventions and depend on newspaper reports, but they are certainly not fake news, they just report what has been happening in the second decade of the 21st century in the People's Republic of China. China is the market leader in robotic technology, including humanoid robotics. Robotics malls are growing in Beijing, one with 4 floors, opened on August 7, 2025, another with 6 floors in Shenzhen. In this large shopping mall, there are robots for all tastes and uses in assisting medicine, industry and everyday activities. They can be bionic, with shapes and movements inspired by biology, or humanoid, reaching levels of sophistication like those seen in a chess player named Wukong. We also find them linked to sport, some play boxing, others football, others practice running, there are artists, for example, painters, musicians and dancers, there are medical assistants, masseurs, nursing technicians and laboratory assistants, and/or dedicated to traditional Chinese medicine, there are them committed to daily tasks, making excellent waiters and cooks, who attentively flip pancakes and prepare barbecues, but also counter staff, there are, in addition, humanoid transporters and drones. And if there are good ones, that is, used to help and build, obviously there could be bad ones, to hinder and destroy. But this is a conversation for later. At the World Robotics Conference in August 2025, held in Beijing, a sales balance was carried out for the year 2024 regarding industrial robots, which exceeded 300 thousand units, keeping China in top place in sales of this type of robots for the twelfth consecutive year. In a report made by the President of the Chinese Robotics Institute, Xu Xiaolan (徐晓兰), the country is the largest producer of robotics in the world, with sales of industrial robots having increased from 33,000 in 2015 to 556,000 units in 2024. The production of service robots (domestic services, storage and logistics, commercial services, support for the elderly, the disabled and rehabilitation medical) for more than 10 million units. In statistical terms, and according to data from the International Data Corporation (IDC) for 2024, Chinese manufacturers occupy 84.7% of the global market for commercial service robots. China leads the world robotics market, through its active creative industry, as it had already done in relation, for example, to toys. The country is responsible for around 80% to 90% of toys sold globally, whether old wooden toys, plush toys, inflatable toys, or electronic toys, with Guangdong, Jiangsu and Shandong being the main bases for purchasing toys, with the centers of Fujian, Zhejiang and Shanghai also being strong in this area. Centers that we also find linked to robotics, at least in the case of Shanghai and Shenzhen. Can a relationship be established between toys and robotics in the case of China? Toys are a strong focus of generation Z, short for zoomers, (those from the second half of the 90s until 2010), who fear a bleak future and invest a lot in emotional spending. This generation of the World Wide Web follows the growth of technological devices, being considered digital native. As I believe, the path to the emergence of robots in China was laid out long before Generation Z appeared on the face of the earth. The Chinese have always loved toys, see their love for stuffed animals, lanterns, old wooden toys and, more recently, all types of electronic toys. Now, robots, although they are much more than entertainment, have the appearance of toys, with the added advantage of being able to receive a strong emotional investment, combined with enormous practical utility. These “cans”, made from aluminum, steel and titanium, and plastics, such as polypropylene, ABS and polycarbonate, rubbers and elastomers, in addition to numerous electronic components, such as microprocessors, sensors, motors and wiring, are great companions of humans, faithful friends and obedience only limited to their manufacture. They therefore appear to fulfill several functions and their emergence was only possible due to a close alliance between science and technology, that is, due to the development of technology, which was thematized by great contemporary writers and philosophers in the West, and think of Aldous Huxley (1894-1963) and his futuristic dystopia, entitled Brave New World. 1932), in which a society dominated by genetic engineering is psychologically conditioned, including by drugs (soma), in order to guarantee social well-being and suppress freedom and critical thinking. Consider, also, works such as Oswald Spengler's (1880-1936), Man and Technique from 1931, which explores the relationship between human beings and technology, ultimately leading to self-destruction through the dissolution of Western culture. But if Western culture can feel, to paraphrase Spengler, “nauseated by machines”, there are others like the philosopher Martin Heidegger (1889-1976), who in The Question of Technique (1954) sees technique as the meaning of a new era for human beings. However, to do so it is necessary to know how to question the technique and not just accept it in an instrumental way at the service of anthropological purposes, when humanism for the philosopher of The Letter to Humanism (1946) has disastrous consequences, because it distances the true man from his essence and Being, which is thus hidden and not revealed. None of these paths of Western thought have been followed by the Chinese of our times, strongly committed to the utilitarian use of technology. The instrumentalization of it at the service of humanity, or rather, of China, does not raise existential doubts in them, as is attested by the large robotics shopping malls currently available in Beijing or Shenzhen to a public eager for technological innovations. Chinese robots serve all types of functions; industrial, commercial, scientific, recreational, domestic and emotional assistance. The relative lack of freedom, or the limitation of degrees of freedom (Degrees of Freedom, DOF) also does not seem worrying to them, at least to the point of raising philosophical questions about a dystopian future, viable through the genetic crossing of artificial intelligence with animals, including so-called rational humans. They only seek to improve the degrees of freedom of robots defined as the number of independent movements of their joints and components, carried out in both the rotational and translational directions, these degrees being in the Humanoid Robotic Technology article, published in May 2025, variable according to the technical improvement of each machine: the greatest degree of freedom is presented by the Era-Star 1 Robot. Therefore, do not expect great and unusual innovations regarding the degree of freedom of robots, they will be, until you see, limited and submissive to their creators. From a good creator a positive robot will emerge, from a bad creator, a negative one. A friend with whom I discussed the topic was very surprised by the fact that one of the most populous countries in the world is at the forefront of robotic development, because for him it would be more important to provide employment to a huge population than to seek to replace them in almost all tasks, from scientific to the most routine, such as the transport and delivery of goods. To understand why this total adherence to intelligent machinery, or as intelligent as its limited freedom allows, it is necessary to go back to the history of China. I propose a journey to the times of the emergence and development of the use of gunpowder. The appearance of gunpowder is associated with Alchemy and Taoist masters, who carried out the first scientific experiments in search of the elixir of longevity, already in the Warring States Period (战国 Zhàn Guó, 475-221 BC), being one of the four great inventions of Ancient China (四大发明Sì dà fāmíng). The first type of gunpowder to emerge was black gunpowder (黑火药Hēi huǒyào), the experiments of the alchemists were very well received and encouraged by the dominant power, then the experiments continued during the Eastern Han dynasty (东汉Dōng Hàn, 25-220), with the treatise by Wei Boyang (魏伯阳), entitled Zhouyi Cantongqi, being famous. (《周易参同契》), and translated as The Concordance of the Three, or that of the Jin dynasty (晋代Jìn dài, 266-420) by the great alchemist Ge Hong (葛洪), whose title is Baopuzi, in Portuguese, The Master Who Embraces Simplicity (《抱朴子·仙药篇》), especially its chapter dedicated to the manufacture of the pill of immortality. Perhaps when using combustion methods to create the pill, the alchemists discovered gunpowder by chance by mixing sulfur, saltpeter and charcoal. It is certain that the explosion occurred and the dangerous, flammable and detonating element was discovered, but it is no less certain that the masters did not follow this route, which they considered unproductive for the desired objective. Then only much later during the Song dynasty (宋代Sòng dài， 960-1279) is it known that some artisans established fireworks workshops in Kaifeng to produce rockets and fireworks indispensable for all great moments of celebration in China. The use of gunpowder then followed two very different paths, one pyrotechnic for recreational purposes of the imperial power and associated stately homes, the other for military use. Why is the story of the discovery of gunpowder brought here? Because this could perhaps contain the three dimensions that we can find in the creation and interest in robots in China. Its creation reveals an enormous scientific interest associated: on the one hand, with philosophical practices aimed at developing life to its limits and perhaps even their absence, which would be achieved by immortality; on the other, it expresses an immense recreational desire with deep emotional investment, and, on the other, a practical utility, which puts robotics at the forefront, both in scientific, military and civil terms. The new Chinese philosophy, as the oldest genuinely autochthonous one, appears in close connection with science and techniques with mysterious connections to the world of magic for the Taoist masters of yesterday, who are followed by the great doctors, including those of traditional Chinese medicine, who today find precious laboratory assistants carrying out work of great precision and minimal errors, since robots do not They get tired, they don't even bother, they do what is asked of them without any salary demands. Furthermore, in military terms this arsenal of machinery is an excellent alternative, as it saves lives, as it is complex and autonomous enough to do so. Obviously, of the many ethical issues associated with this exponential development of the new world of robotics and artificial intelligence, one seems essential, above all and, for now, in terms of biotechnical experimentation and related scientific research, which will be discussed below. First the example, taken from the development of dynamic electrodes for brain-computer interface, as is happening at the Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. In brain-computer interface systems, electrodes from electronic devices must be connected to the brain to acquire electroencephalographic signals. These electrodes are made of flexible fiber, similar to a worm, with a magnetic sensor incorporated in the head of the “worm”, to be manipulated according to the orientation of external magnetic fields. These flexible fiber electrodes were introduced into the brains of rabbits and also rats, with the aim of subsequently serving human clinical needs, such as intelligent control of prostheses, localization of epileptic lesions and treatment of chronic neurological disorders. From an ethical point of view, the question cannot help but be asked: why are human lives more important than all others on our planet? Human beings remain the kings of creation, even within the scope of philosophies such as the Chinese, whose non-humanist tradition, as referred to in Heidegger's Letter to Humanism, is well known. Are we humans really that valuable? Science must continue its path, which in China will always be followed from a pragmatic and utilitarian perspective for the benefit of the Chinese and the Chinese nation. But don't think that robotics is there just to serve Chinese society without exchanging favors, as we cannot forget the enormous emotional investment that the population that descends from Dragons makes in these new beings, some more bionic than others, who acquire the status of companions and friends and, in this capacity, have all the pampering that was previously due to the humans and animals they chose to cherish. The new Chinese philosophy is utilitarian, practical and has new entities in its world of knowledge, such as humanoids, bionic robots and robotics toys. They are highly esteemed and paving the way for a new era, that of cyborgs or better said, the mixed humanity of tomorrow, which will have the greatest chance of living long and, who knows, immortalizing itself. item.title: Death | António Coelho dies aged 77, but leaves a legacy in Portuguese gastronomy
item.description: The founder of Restaurante António died on Sunday in Macau, due to heart problems. Behind him, he leaves a mark and an innovative concept for promoting Portuguese food in Asia A father, a friend and one of the great ambassadors of Portuguese gastronomy in Asia. Chef António Coelho died on Sunday, aged 77, due to heart problems, but leaves behind a professional career spanning almost 40 years and an influence that can be felt in several restaurants and Portuguese food chefs in Macau. Born in Portugal in 1948, António Coelho's first contact with Macau took place in 1970, when he had to complete his four-year mandatory military service. After two years, the land remained in his memory, but the future chef chose to return to Europe. In Portugal, he started working at Social Security, later moving to a clinical analysis laboratory. It was in this area that he developed his taste for gastronomy, not through work, but through various lunches and dinners in different restaurants. Increasingly interested in cooking, António decided to take a job, in 1984, in a restaurant, where he admitted to having learned to cook, according to an interview with the South China Morning Post newspaper, in 2018. The first years of António Coelho's new career were spent in Portugal, where he performed different roles as manager-administrator of the Botequim do Rei restaurant or director of the catering department at the Grande Hotel da Curia. In 1996, he had his first international experience, as director of the restaurant department at the Hotel Trópico, in Cape Verde. The experience lasts one year. Creating a legacy Returning to Macau in 1997, António worked for 10 years in different spaces, such as the restaurants Frol de la Mar, Lusitano, Lisbon, and also had a brief stay in Hong Kong, in 2002, at Restaurante Inn. However, the decisive step towards his affirmation as one of the most influential chefs of Portuguese gastronomy in Asia came in 2007, with the opening of Restaurante António. And the success that followed was not the result of chance, as said by Edgar Rodrigues, a chef who came to Macau to work on the launch of the project: “The success was based on the recipes, the quality of the food, but also the very professionalism”, says Edgar Rodrigues, to HM. "He was very attentive to his customers. If there was an order for clams à bolhão pato, he would have different recipes adapted to the nationality. For example, Koreans don't like coriander, the recipe for them didn't have coriander. Chinese customers like little salt, they were served with little salt, and locals like the more traditional recipe. In a single dish there were several ways of cooking, just to satisfy different customers", he recalls. Cristiano Tavares, currently chef at the Macalhau restaurant, also came to Macau to work at the António Restaurant. He believes that the chef found a position for Portuguese food that still influences other restaurants today. “I think his success was due to his way of being, he was a politically correct person, he had a way of working that pleased both Chinese, Korean and Japanese tourists”, explained Cristiano Tavares, to HM. "We were a street restaurant with four or five cooks. He managed to do what many large restaurants still cannot do today. Nowadays there are many restaurants with Portuguese food that open in Macau, but follow the example of what he did", he considered. Quality and spectacle In addition to the food, Restaurante António customers were seduced by the “show”. This is the vision of Marcelino Marques, António's friend and musician who for several years livened up the space's nights, with traditional Portuguese music. "The quality of the food made the space popular. He took great care in choosing the food and drinks served. He went to Portugal to choose wines from various regions, such as Douro or Alentejo, all of high quality, which were bottled under the António brand. People knew they weren't going to pay little, not that it was a space with luxury prices, it wasn't, but the quantity served wasn't small", recalled Marcelino Marques. However, the musician believes that the success was also due to a concept in which the meal was also a spectacle: "People liked listening to Portuguese music, but also being with António. He was an affable, big person and appeared in that white jacket with the flags of Portugal, China and Macau and people liked his presence and asked him to take photographs", he says. "He also opened a bottle of champagne with a sword. He did a whole ceremony and people really liked it. It was a spectacle and a party to see the cork flying out of the bottle. It worked well", he recalled. Marcelino Marques recalls that the food and the show made the restaurant very famous, especially among Japanese, Korean and Hong Kong tourists. The musician reveals that Japanese tourists booked days in advance. And this factor also contributed to the fact that António offered a glass of port wine at the end of the meal, which also led to the recognition of the Port Wine Confraternity. The success of Restaurante António led the chef to sell the space to an investment fund, becoming an ambassador for the space. The break with the fund happened in 2020, when he was fired without just cause. The case ended up in court, with António winning the case. In recent years, António took on the position of executive chef at Angela’s Café and Lounge, at the Hotel Lisboeta. A father, a friend Due to his work in Macau, António was distinguished, in 2013, by the Macao SAR Government with the MSAR Tourist Merit Medal. Also in 2015, he received the merit medal for Portuguese communities from the Portuguese Government. However, for those who worked with him the most important thing was the relationship that went beyond the strictly professional field. "He had a big impact on Macau and for me he was like a second father. When I came to Macau I didn't have an easy life and he always held my hand", confessed Rodrigues. "He was always a person who was there for me. And I always saw him as a man of iron. In everything he did, there was a great will", he pointed out. This is a feeling shared by Cristiano Tavares. "António is my father in Macau. He worked until the last day, always with seriousness, honesty and integrity. He is an example for all the chefs in this area", he said. For Marcelino Marques, António's death is the loss of a friend. "António was the person who welcomed me to Macau and was capable of doing the same to everyone. He was strict and demanding, but he was an excellent person", he described. "Everyone knew him. He was an affable person and received people like no one else", he added.

item.title: Chemistry | Nobel Prize for the development of metal-organic structures
item.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Susumu Kitagawa, from Kyoto University, Richard Robson, from the University of Melbourne, and Omar M. Yaghi, from the University of California, “for the development of metal-organic structures”, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences announced yesterday. Susumu Kitagawa, Richard Robson and Omar Yaghi have developed a new form of molecular architecture – metal-organic frameworks – that can be used to collect water from desert air, capture carbon dioxide, store toxic gases or catalyze chemical reactions. The three laureates created molecular constructs with large spaces through which gases and other chemicals could flow. The president of the Nobel Committee for Chemistry, Heiner Linque, highlighted precisely the fact that these “metal-organic structures have enormous potential, bringing previously unforeseen opportunities for personalized materials with new functions”. The research that led to the discovery of this new form of molecular architecture began nearly four decades ago, in 1989, when Richard Robson tested the use of the inherent properties of atoms by combining positively charged copper ions with a four-armed molecule. When combined, they bonded "to form a spacious, well-ordered crystal. It was like a diamond filled with countless cavities," the academy explains. Robson immediately realized the potential of his molecular construction, but it was still unstable and crumbled easily. It was chemists Susumu Kitagawa and Omar Yaghi who managed to provide a solid foundation for this construction method. Notable applications Following the discoveries of the three laureates, chemists built tens of thousands of different MOFs. Some of them could contribute to solving some of humanity's biggest challenges, with applications including breaking down traces of pharmaceuticals in the environment, capturing carbon dioxide or collecting water from desert air. The discovery also allows the separation of perfluoroalkylated and polyfluoroalkylated substances (PFAS) from water. PFAS are a group of synthetic chemical compounds known as “forever chemicals” due to their extreme persistence in the environment and in the human body. PFAS are used in a wide range of industrial and household products, such as stain- and water-resistant textiles, food packaging, non-stick cookware and firefighting foams. Its accumulation in the environment and potential health risks, including liver damage and other problems, have led to concerns and a search for safer alternatives.

item.title: Study | Trump was the main disseminator of disinformation in the USA in 2024
item.description: North American President Donald Trump was the main disseminator of disinformation in the United States of America (USA) in 2024, concluded a study by the International Center for Journalists (ICFJ). “US President Donald Trump was the dominant source and distributor of disinformation” in 2024, say the authors of the study “Disarming Disinformation: United States”. The study highlights that Trump has drawn on the functions of domestic political forces, rather than foreign state actors, as the main source of disinformation narratives in US political discourse. Furthermore, the existence of WhatsApp groups and other closed digital spaces often act as “information cocoons” that encourage rumors and other forms of misinformation. In this way, "the viral spread of misinformation and the strategic attack on journalists have emerged as interconnected threats to democracy. In an era of increasing authoritarianism and democratic backsliding, falsehoods are often used as a weapon by state actors to influence public opinion, undermine journalism and intimidate journalists." The study authors state that these factors are increasingly the North American reality, with Donald Trump “promulgating manifestly false narratives” in recent years. “The American media faces a profound information crisis, at a time of repression of freedom of expression”, the study reads. In this sense, trust in the mainstream press continues to decline in a climate of increasing attacks on the media by the Trump Government. The study published by the International Center for Journalists (ICFJ) was based on the analysis of 10,000 news and media publications during 2024, as well as a survey of 1,020 Americans.

item.title: Scientists ‘reduce’ the age of the Egyptian temple of Karnak, in Egypt
item.description: Researchers have carried out the most comprehensive geoarchaeological study of the Karnak temple, near Luxor, and revealed suggestive links to ancient Egyptian mythology and new data about the interaction between the complex's riverine landscape and the people who occupied the site during its almost 3,000 years of use. The results of the investigation were published on Monday in Antiquity magazine, reported the Efe news agency. Researchers from the University of Southampton, in the United Kingdom, and Uppsala University, in Sweden, participated in the study. Up to 61 sediment samples from the interior and surroundings of the temple and thousands of ceramic fragments found in the Karnak complex, located 500 meters east of the current Nile River, near Luxor, in the ancient Egyptian religious capital of Thebes, were analyzed. The researchers mapped how the landscape around the site changed throughout its history and found that, before 2520 BC, the site could not have been suitable for permanent occupation due to periodic flooding caused by the Nile's strong currents. Therefore, they placed the earliest occupation at Karnak during the Old Kingdom (between 2591 and 2152 BC). Pottery fragments found at the site corroborate this discovery, with the oldest dating between 2305 and 1980 BC. Therefore, the conclusions of this international team of researchers provide new evidence about the age of Karnak, which has been hotly debated in archaeological circles for decades. The origin of everything The ground on which the temple was founded was formed when river channels advanced west and east, creating an island of high ground in what is now the east-southeast region of the site. This emerging island laid the foundation for the occupation and initial construction of Karnak. Over the following centuries and millennia, the river channels on both sides of the site diverged further, creating more space for the development of the temple complex, as researchers have now confirmed. This new understanding of the temple's landscape bears striking similarities to an ancient Egyptian creation myth, leading the team to believe that the decision to locate the temple there may have been related to the religious views of its inhabitants. Ancient Egyptian texts from the Old Kingdom indicate that the 'Creator God' manifested himself as high ground emerging from the lake, and researchers have found that the island where Karnak was founded is the only known area of ​​high ground surrounded by water in the region. Thus, archaeologists have suggested that the Theban elites chose the location of Karnak to be the abode of a new form of 'Creator God', alluding to Amun-Ra, the supreme god of ancient Egypt, since the location fit perfectly into the mythological setting of the highlands that emerged from the surrounding waters as the origin of the formation of the Universe.

item.title: Physics | Nobel Prize for Macroscopic Quantum Mechanical Tunneling
item.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret and John M. Martinis “for the discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunneling and the quantization of energy in an electrical circuit”, announced yesterday the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. "An important question in physics is the maximum size of a system capable of demonstrating the effects of quantum mechanics. This year's Nobel Prize laureates carried out experiments with an electrical circuit in which they demonstrated both quantum tunneling and quantized energy levels in a system large enough to be held in the hand", explains the Swedish Academy of Sciences in a statement published on its website. The British John Clarke carried out his research at the University of California, Berkeley, USA; the American John Martinis at the University of California, Santa Barbara; and the Frenchman Michel Devoret at Yale University and also in California, Santa Barbara. According to academia, quantum mechanics allows a particle to directly cross a barrier, through a process called tunneling. When a large number of particles are involved, quantum effects usually become negligible. The experiments of the now distinguished scientists demonstrated that quantum properties can be made concrete on a macroscopic scale. "It is wonderful to be able to celebrate the way in which quantum mechanics, more than a century old, continues to offer new surprises. It is also extremely useful, as it is the basis of all digital technology", said the president of the Nobel Committee for Physics, Olle Eriksson, quoted in the statement. The Swedish academy says that transistors in computer microchips are an example of consolidated quantum technology. The scientists today awarded the Nobel Prize for Physics share a prize of 11 million Swedish kronor (almost one million euros).

item.title: Linguistics | Published study based on a trip to Macau in the 19th century
item.description:
Academic Anabela Leal de Barros has just published a linguistic study that focuses on the trip of Father Miranda e Oliveira, linked to the Congregation of the Mission, to Macau in 1825. With touches of history, details are revealed about the Portuguese of the time and of Macau. The book will be presented at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center next Wednesday
“Journey from Lisbon to Macau – 1825” is the title of the most recent work published by Grão-Falar, written by University of Minho academic Anabela Leal de Barros. The book makes a critical and interpretative analysis of the Portuguese of the time left in the manuscript of parish priest José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira, priest of the Congregation of the Mission. This documentation is kept by the Braga District Archive. However, the work does not just explore the Portuguese of the time, revealing other historical details of Macau, Asia and a sea voyage. As Anabela Leal de Barros told HM, the work is “as faithful as possible to the spelling of the manuscript”, until now practically unknown. In this travel diary, Father Miranda e Oliveira “reveals enormous curiosity about all the news and shares with us their names in the languages ​​of the world in which they were baptized, starting with ours”. This is how he explains situations such as “seasickness, a reality that was still relatively unknown and highly invasive on boats” in those times. The priest named or defined “the mangalhões, the porpoises, the caravels, the black-eyed peas, the flies, the albacores — all sorts of birds and fish that were admired, fished or tasted throughout the trip”, or even the “meteorological phenomena with local names – cacimba, samatra, typhoon”. There are also details about “cultural habits such as the masca, buio in Indonesian; the Philippine seges, the berloches, and the ruling class of the camisolas, as well as the sômas, Chinese vessels”. The vessel left Lisbon in April 1825 and spent time in the Philippines, arriving in Macau on October 23rd. The arrival “to the island of Caó” and the following day “to Colégio de S. José” is described, to “a city with ‘a magnificent port of commerce’, located ‘on a very pleasant peninsula’, with ‘good waters’ and ‘famous European-style buildings'”. Linguistic varieties In the work published by Grão-Falar there are, for example, “rich stories such as that of Orvalhadas de S. João, Caldeirão de Frei Junípero or the habit of seafarers shouting ‘Refresca S. Lourenço!’ so that the wind blows, this being the meaning here of ‘refresh’”. There are also “allusions to the linguistic variety itself”, as “at various times there is reference to communication with foreigners carried out in Latin, in Indonesian-Dutch and Filipino-Spanish territory; the private teaching of English in the Philippines by members of the Congregation of the Mission; the little knowledge and use of Spanish, even in Manila, and the variation of Tagalog itself, a language in which the priest is concerned about recording the Hail Mary.” Before arriving at this travel report, Anabela Leal de Barros was already in the intricacies of investigating this type of manuscripts, coming across the story of another priest, “the greatest Portuguese sinologist, Joaquim Afonso Gonçalves, who had traveled from the same house as Rilhafoles of the Congregation of the Mission to Macau in 1812”. According to the author, this parish priest “dedicated the last twenty-nine years of his life to the mission of evangelization in China, and in particular to the research and teaching of Chinese at the Colégio de S. José in Macau”. In his entire life, “this Trás-os-Montes native wrote more than five thousand pages of grammars and dictionaries in Portuguese, Latin and Chinese, expressly dedicated to his students at the College, seven printed in his typography and at least two manuscripts”. Then, in 2017, António Lázaro, from the History Department of the University of Minho, and director of the Confúcio Institute, made available to Anabela Leal de Barros “a list of references to manuscripts from the Braga District Archive about Macau and China”. A “journey” began, which culminated in the publication of this study. “This book is the first result of a project of mine to edit and study unpublished travel literature manuscripts whose main objective is exactly this: to contribute to the appreciation and consolidation of the micro-history of the Discoveries and the memory of history, between the 15th and 19th centuries”. Accompanied on the trip José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira took around seven months to arrive in Macau, leaving Lisbon on April 1, 1825, and arriving in Oriente on October 24 of the same year. He left on the ship Vasco da Gama with three other priests from the congregation: João da França de Castro e Moura, Jerónimo José da Mata and José́ Ferreira da Silva. According to Anabela Leal de Barros, “the manuscript does not appear to have been cleaned by the author himself, given the type of spelling variations and typos and amendments it presents”, having probably been “translated, to safeguard copies, by a Macanese member of the College, since Macau Portuguese, in the 19th century, had characteristics compatible with certain traits, strange in a priest arrived from Portugal, even how young.” This travel diary “ends on the very day of arrival in Macau, with a very brief presentation of the city and the school, making clear the Catholic perspective of the time in relation to the Chinese cult of ancestors and without failing to draw attention to the mere five thousand Christians among the 40 to 50 thousand inhabitants of the city”. Political hostilities José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira describes how the bishop of Macau did not receive the delegation, which is “enough to lead us to the hostile context in which the Lazarists, defenders of liberalism, found themselves, which had led Joaquim Afonso Gonçalves, a few years earlier, to take refuge in the Philippines, with the school missing two of its teachers”. Furthermore, “along the journey the priest does not fail to narrate all the moments in which he carries out his daily mission, with the administration of the sacraments, the prayer of responsos and the celebration of masses, but above all he notes the notable lack of priests who reveal the Christianized peoples, particularly in Batavia, now Jakarta, where the community of Portuguese origin, of more than a thousand people, had only an old priest.” These reports also reveal the concern to “remember the first French martyrs of the Congregation in the attempt to evangelize Madagascar and to report the presence of friars and priests from the different congregations, from Cape Verde to the Philippines, where they are recognized as more important for the solidity of Spanish rule than its army”. According to Anabela Leal de Barros, the report also alluded, in Java, “to the Lutherans and Mohammedans, as well as to the religions of China and, in Manila, to the persecution of Christians (referring to the ‘dinner’, that is, lunch with a Chinese Christian, ‘and as such persecuted’)”. Miranda and Oliveira had “a very diplomatic and convivial conduct, ensuring the establishment and maintenance of cordial relations between the various orders and also with the governors and foreign powers present, from the Dutch to the Spanish, who visited everywhere”. An ongoing project In those years, it was a dangerous adventure to travel by boat, facing “anthropogenic peoples, piracy, diseases on ships and epidemics”, a “perfectly cinematic vision” already described in Os Lusíadas, by Luís de Camões. Those who embarked on these trips also found themselves alone, “individually and on a small ship little more than a walnut shell, facing an endless sea, for months, at times when it was common for several passengers not to reach their destination, or for not even one ship from a full squadron to return”. In Miranda and Oliveira's report, “there is no great news” compared to previous reports, but “we are aware of the main difficulties of sea voyages to Asia in the 19th century: the rocks that existed even before the Torre de Belém, which caused many shipwrecks; and seasickness, which even deserves a definition for the many readers who had never set foot on a boat, and to which the captain's face advising the sick ladies going up to the awning and working, as it was the best medicine”. There is also “the episode of the man falling overboard from the plow that accompanied them on part of the trip, which they were unable to save — a death to which everyone was so exposed, as the narrator refers”. Another potential misfortune in trips of this type also stands out, “the encounter with ships that, not immediately raising any flag, or raising it without giving true confidence, immediately led to the decision to light the hills and open fire, which well reflects the dimension of piracy and the fears it imposed”. Essentially, “the main character of sea voyages was the wind”, which led the still “young priest” to “evoke the Camonian verses of the storm twice”. After arriving in Macau, Miranda e Oliveira left for his post in Nanking, “on a journey comparatively longer than the first, received by the Christians with difficulty and secretly”. “In the face of persecution” he ended up succumbing “to the dangers and illnesses of the mainland, at the age of 31, far from all his confreres, on November 1, 1828, just two years after having described the difficult farewell to his spiritual family, in Lisbon”. “His traveling companions had more longevity, one of whom would become Bishop of Macau and the other of Beijing and Porto”, highlights Anabela Leal de Barros.

item.title: Airport | Expansion guarantees capacity for 13 million visitors
item.description:
Even before the increase in passenger capacity, the airport will receive a larger parking area for aircraft, with the number of spaces increasing to 56 compared to the current 36
By the end of 2030, Macau International Airport will have the capacity to receive 13 million passengers per year. The figures were presented by a representative of the Civil Aviation Authority (AACM), at the most recent meeting of the Islands' Community Services Advisory Council, which took place on Monday. The summary of the meeting was given to the newspaper Ou Mun by counselors Li Yongjian and Ieong Weng Kuong, who cited the responses from the AACM meeting. According to the explanations mentioned, expansion works are underway, after having started in April. The new parking area is expected to be completed in 2028, which will increase aircraft parking spaces from the current 36 to 56 spaces, an increase of 55.6 percent. At the same time, it was indicated that estimates indicate that the expansion works will be fully completed in 2030, within around five years, and that at that time the airport will have the capacity to handle another two million travelers, compared to the current capacity of 11 million per year. Last year, the airport received 7.6 million travelers, two million fewer than the record number of passengers reached in 2019, even before the pandemic, when there were 9.6 million travelers using the infrastructure. However, the number appears to show a further reduction. Between January and October this year, around 5.5 million passengers were recorded. Last year, in the first ten months, there were 5.7 million passengers. Largest area With ongoing work, the total area of ​​the airport will be increased to 325 hectares, compared to the current 177 hectares. At the meeting, the councilors also addressed other issues related to the airport, such as issues related to security and passenger transport between the boarding pier and the planes. In this sense, counselors were assured that given the current limitations on the number of boarding lanes available, that passenger transportation between the boarding pier and the aircraft will continue to be done via buses. This will also be the method used for future aircraft parking spaces. During the meeting, according to Li Yongjian and Ieong Weng Kuong, there were also advisors calling for the development of more complementary facilities at the airport, as well as paying special attention to ensuring that the transport center is prepared to deal with the flow of passengers that occurs during large-scale events, such as the recent NBA pre-season games in Macau.

item.title: Sam Hou Fai talks about “new phase” of the principle of one country, two systems
item.description: The Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, said yesterday that “Macau has entered the new phase of applying the principle of one country, two systems” and that it is struggling “with profound and complex changes in the internal and external environment”, in addition to that the world finds itself “in a new period of turbulence and change”. Speaking at an event celebrating the 105th anniversary of the Macau Red Cross Foundation, Sam Hou Fai recalled that “compatriots need more humanistic care and spiritual comfort”, and therefore hopes that the Red Cross “will continue to pay attention and support to the development of the Macao SAR and the Government's actions”. The governor defended that this century-old organization must be attentive to “government plans and demands for the high-quality development of Macau in the new journey”, with the hope that there will be reinforced cooperation with the Chinese Red Cross Society. Long life The Chief Executive highlighted that the Macau Red Cross has been “rooted” in the territory since 1920, and, in addition to “serving Macau, it also closely monitors and supports humanitarian services and activities of public interest in Mainland China and internationally”. The highest ruler of the MSAR did not forget the moment of transition, when the “Red Cross of Macau officially became the Delegation with a high degree of autonomy of the Red Cross Society of China, being a witness, participant and contributor to the successful application of the principle of one country, two systems with Macau characteristics”. Still on governance, Sam Hou Fai promised to “build a Macau based on the rule of law, dynamic, cultural and happy”, continuing with the “focus on supporting the most vulnerable layers” and assuming “the reinforcement of the feeling of fulfillment, happiness and security of all Macau residents as the starting point and basis of government action”. It was also guaranteed that the Executive “will fully support the Macau Red Cross in the planning and development of activities”.

item.title: Hainan | Taking advantage of Macau to import Portuguese-speaking products
item.description:
During a visit to Forum Macau, governor Liu Xiaoming said he wanted to create synergies with the Macao SAR so that Portuguese-speaking products can enter the interior
The leader of the island of Hainan stated yesterday that he wants to help Portuguese-speaking products enter the Chinese market, defending synergies with Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries. Governor Liu Xiaoming pointed out as a goal “the construction of Hainan as a hub for the entry of products from Portuguese-speaking countries into the interior of China”. Liu was speaking during a visit to the facilities of the Forum for Economic and Trade Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries, known as the Macau Forum. According to Forum Macau, the leader of Hainan asked the organization for support, also to help companies on the island “to deepen their knowledge of market rules and investment environments in Portuguese-speaking nations”. According to a statement, Liu defended the bet on “synergistic development between Hainan, Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries” and recalled that the island will become a free port before the end of the year. From December 18, imported products that are processed in Hainan – with an added value of at least 30 percent – ​​can enter mainland China without paying customs duties. Bet on the advantages On Monday, even before going to Forum Macau, Liu Xiaoming had a meeting with Sam Hou Fai. According to a statement from the Macau Government, Sam argued that there may be “complementarity of advantages” between the free port of Hainan and the Deep Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau. This special economic zone, jointly managed by Guangdong province and Macau, was launched by Beijing and 2021 and covers around 106 square kilometers on Mountain Island, adjacent to Macau. China established Macau as a platform for strengthening economic and trade cooperation with Portuguese-speaking countries in 2003 and, in that same year, created the Macau Forum. The organization includes, in addition to China, the nine Portuguese-speaking countries: Angola, Brazil, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Portugal, São Tomé and Príncipe, Timor-Leste and, since 2022, Equatorial Guinea. Exports from Portuguese-speaking countries to China fell 11.3 percent to $86.6 billion in the first eight months of the year, according to official data.

item.title: AL | Deputies take office this morning
item.description: The deputies of the Legislative Assembly take office this morning for the beginning of the VIII Legislature. The oath is scheduled for 11 am, in the meeting room of the Service Platform Complex for Commercial Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries.
