In the afternoon, at 3pm, the first session of the Plenary of the Legislative Assembly is scheduled, which will serve to elect the future president, vice-president, first secretary and second secretary. After the meeting, there will be another oath session, on the same day, at 4 pm, and the AL president will be sworn in. The session also takes place at the Service Platform Complex for Commercial Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries. Following the government reshuffle, Wong Sio Chak and Chan Tsz King will hold the oath and inauguration ceremony this morning, at 10am, at the Government headquarters. Wong Sio Chak will take on the role of Secretary for Administration and Justice, while Chan Tsz King will be the new Secretary for Security. In the 10 am session, the first of three that will take place tomorrow, the oath ceremony and inauguration of Tong Hio Fong as Prosecutor of the Macao SAR and the new members of the Executive Council are also scheduled. The ceremony is not open to the public. AMCM | Chan Kuan I appointed to Board of Directors Chan Kuan I was appointed member of the Board of Directors of the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM). The measure comes into force next Monday, according to an order from Sam Hou Fai, published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. With a degree in Commerce (Accounting) from Monash University in Australia and a master's degree in Public Administration taught by Peking University and the Chinese Academy of Governance, Chan has been part of the AMCM staff since August 2001, although with a break between 2006 and 2009, when she worked in the Financial Information Office. After returning to AMCM, the new member performed the functions of technician, deputy director and director of the Insurance Supervision Department. DSSCU | Chan Hoi Ieng appointed deputy director Raymond Tam appointed Chan Hoi Ieng, one of his office advisors, as deputy director of the Land and Urban Construction Services Directorate (DSSCU). The appointment was revealed yesterday through the Official Bulletin. Chan Hoi Ieng has a degree in Engineering from Tsinghua University and a Master's degree in Public Administration from Peking University. At a professional level, she was a senior technician between December 1999 and November 2016 at the then Institute for Civic and Municipal Affairs. Between 2016 and 2022, she performed the same type of functions in the Customs Services, until December of last year, when she was promoted to advisor. Also in December last year, she was appointed advisor to the Office of the Secretary for Transport and Public Works. She is now chosen as deputy director of DSSCU.

item.title: DSAT | Chiang Ngoc Vai takes over as director
item.description:
After almost 20 years at the head of the department responsible for traffic, Chiang was promoted to the top of the hierarchy. Since July, he has performed his duties as a substitute after Lam Hin San's departure
After three months as deputy director of the Directorate of Traffic Affairs Services (DSAT), Chiang Ngoc Vai took over the portfolio in his own capacity yesterday. The information was revealed through an order published in the Official Bulletin, signed by Raymond Tam, Secretary for Transport and Public Works. In addition to three months as deputy director, Chiang Ngoc Vai has a career spanning almost 20 years at DSAT, a service he joined for the first time in 2008, soon to assume the role of deputy director. From that time, until July of this year, Chiang remained as deputy director and it was in this capacity in recent months that he assumed the role of director, after the departure of his predecessor, Lam Hin San. The promotion confirmed yesterday, and the removal of Lam Hin San, also show Raymond Tam's break with the past, given that Chiang's predecessor had been appointed by the previous Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raimundo do Rosário, deserving his trust for around 10 years. The order does not indicate any particular reasons for the appointment, other than the pro-forma indicating that Chiang Ngoc Vai “has professional competence and aptitude for the role” and the nominee's CV. As with service commission appointments, the secretary's choice is valid for a period of one year. From engineering In academic terms, the order indicates that Chiang Ngoc has two degrees in Civil Engineering and Science (Cadastral Topography and Spatial Planning). The teaching institutions for the degrees are not mentioned. On a professional level, the director of DSAT has a long history in Public Administration, spanning more than 30 years. Chiang joined the Directorate of Land, Public Works and Transport Services in October 1990, working as a technician. In March 1992, he was promoted within the same department, to assume the role of head of sector. Even before the transfer, in 1995, Chiang Ngoc Vai was once again promoted internally to take on the role of senior technician and also Head of Department. He remained in these roles until 2008, for another 13 years, when he was appointed to DSAT.

item.title: Deputy Lei Chan U praises new diploma on administrative reform
item.description: A new diploma in the area of ​​administrative reform was published this Monday, entitled “General regime for the creation and organic structure of public services and entities”. In this way, two decree-laws that had been in force in the territory since the 1980s were reviewed. Lei Chan U, recently re-elected deputy to the Legislative Assembly (AL), issued a statement arguing that this legislative change constitutes “an important milestone in the reform of public administration, contributing to solving persistent problems”, namely the “constant reorganization of services, the excessively cumbersome structure and the lack of clarity in the responsibilities” of leaders. The official also declared that this reformulation will improve “governmental effectiveness and promote the creation of an efficient Government focused on serving citizens”. In the same statement, the deputy recalled the fact that the last Governments have “sought to promote the reform of Public Administration” although problems such as cumbersome structures, “the overlapping of functions and the lack of definition of competences have never been effectively resolved”. Light at the end of the tunnel In this way, Lei Chan U understands that this new administrative regulation defines “clear criteria for the creation of new public services, stipulating that it will only be allowed to create new departments when new functions arise that cannot be performed by adjusting existing structures”. It is also mentioned that the “number of public services will be reduced from more than 70 to 47, achieving a true ‘cleaning’ of the administrative machinery”, he declared. Another rule defined in the administrative regulation is the prohibition, on the part of public services, of “creating new subunits at sector and section level”. Lei Chan U said he hopes that “the Government will continue to strengthen the coordination and planning” of the administrative machinery, by promoting “the review of structures and functions of public services in a gradual, orderly manner and based on the principle of objectivity”, in order to build “an efficient, capable and public service-oriented Government”.

item.title: Diplomacy | Liu Xianfa called for an end to US “attacks” on the Macao SAR
item.description:
The MNE Commissioner in Macau showed his dissatisfaction to the United States Consul General in Hong Kong and Macau, Julie Eadeh, with the “so-called annual reports” published by the United States on the MSAR, which he stated contained “attacks and defamation”
The Commissioner of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Macau, Liu Xianfa, called on the US consul general in Hong Kong and Macau, Julie Eadeh, to end “the attacks and defamation” against Macau in the annual reports. The request came during a telephone call made by Julie Eadeh to Liu Xianfa, on October 10, according to a post on the social network Facebook, on the page of the Commissariat of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the Macao SAR. In August, Julie Eadeh was chosen by the United States as the new consul general in Hong Kong and Macau, succeeding Greg May. As part of the new functions, and given that the area of ​​action also includes Macau, the American representative made a “courtesy telephone call” to Liu Xianfa. During the phone call, the commissioner told Eadeh that he hopes the United States will take a constructive role in Macau's development and that “the attacks and defamation” will end. “Commissioner Liu called on the US side to end the attacks and defamation against Macau in the so-called annual reports, not to compromise the security and stability of Macau and not to impede the prosperity and development of Macau,” the statement said. At issue are the reports published annually by the State Department on human rights, religious freedom or human trafficking. Liu Xianfa also indicated to Julie Eadeh the hope that she “will act in a way that promotes exchanges and cooperation between Macau and the US” and that she will “play a constructive role in the stable, solid and sustainable development of relations between China and the US”. Safeguard cooperation According to the version of the Commissioner of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Macau, during the telephone call, Julie Eadeh highlighted that “involvement and cooperation with Macau in trade, investment and exchange between people are important for the USA” and that she will play an “active role” in achieving this exchange. Julie Eadeh has a Bachelor of Science degree from Eastern Michigan University and a Master's degree in Contemporary Arabic Studies from Georgetown University. He was part of the US Department of State, until joining the American Consular Services in 2004. Throughout his career he spent time at embassies in the Middle East, in countries such as Saudi Arabia, Lebanon or Iraq. In 2010, he became US consul general in Shanghai, a position he held until 2012. He also served as head of the political section at the US Consulate in Hong Kong, which he will now lead.

item.title: In Memoriam by Chef António Coelho
item.description: “I love Portuguese food. I love the traditional and authentic cuisine. It’s the one I learned in Portugal. For me, that’s very important because I prefer the traditional things.” Chef António Neves Coelho The guardian of Portuguese-Macanese cuisine and dear friend, Chef António das Neves Coelho, left us on October 12, 2025, at Hospital Conde de São Januário. Major figure of Portuguese gastronomy in Macau, mentor to generations, defender of culinary authenticity and symbol of institutional resilience. His departure represents an irreparable loss for the gastronomic culture of the Macao SAR and for the emotional memory of all who shared his table, kitchen and dreams with him. Chef António grew up amidst the aromas of olive oil, garlic and red wine. From an early age, he revealed a rare vocation for cooking, not just as a technique, but as a cultural narrative. His training took place in emblematic houses of Portuguese gastronomy, where he learned to respect the ingredients, times and affections that make up the culinary tradition. His international career took him to three continents and, finally, to Macau, where he completed his military service and found his true stage. From 1997 onwards, he established himself as Executive Chef and operations manager in reference spaces, becoming one of the main ambassadors of Portuguese and Macanese cuisine. Macau was not only his professional destination but his spiritual home. António understood that Macanese cuisine is not just a fusion of flavors, but also of stories. With sensitivity and rigor, he became a defender of the preservation of traditional recipes, the valorization of local ingredients and the formation of multicultural teams with a spirit of mission. He founded his own brand, where he worked as culinary director and general manager for more than a decade at António Restaurante, receiving 12 Michelin recommendations, among others. His leadership was marked by a rare combination of technical demands, human empathy and strategic vision. His cuisine was made of olive oil and affection, of technique and tenderness, of rigor and poetry. Its contribution was recognized by two highly prestigious distinctions such as the Medal of Tourist Merit, awarded by the Government of the Macao SAR, in recognition of its role in the development of the hospitality sector and local gastronomic culture and the Medal of Merit of Portuguese Communities, awarded by the Government of Portugal, for its action as a cultural bridge between continents and for the promotion of Portuguese identity abroad. These honors were not just trophies but testimonies of his dedication to the public cause, culture and excellence. In 2024, Chef António took on the leadership of a new gastronomic project at Angela Café & Lounge at Lisboeta Macau. There, he created a menu that celebrated the Portuguese and Macanese essence, with dishes such as codfish à lagareiro, seafood rice and desserts with a conventual touch. The space has become a meeting point between tradition and modernity, between tourists and locals, between memory and the future. His team, formed and inspired by him, continues to represent the pillars of his vision with dedication, creativity and commitment to excellence. Chef António's death represents a human and institutional loss of great significance. But his legacy remains alive in the memory of the customers who tasted his dishes; in the training of professionals who learned from him; in the institutional identity of the spaces he helped to build and in the gastronomic culture of Macau and the Portuguese diaspora His work does not end with his departure but continues in each preserved recipe, in each technical gesture transmitted and in each ethical value defended. More than a Chef, António was the guardian of the Portuguese-Macanese gastronomic soul. His life was a bridge between continents, flavors and generations. His cuisine was made of memory and innovation, of technique and tenderness, of rigor and poetry. May his memory continue to live on in every dish served, in every story told and in every young professional who dares to dream of a cuisine that respects the past and transforms the present. Before his departure, Chef António left his legatee a precious set of recipes that are not mere technical records, but authentic trophies of Portuguese cuisine, honed over decades of practice, reflection and passion. This legacy is not just a gastronomic collection but a cultural heritage, a letter of intent and a mission to fulfill. Each recipe represents a chapter of your life, a shared memory, a silent tribute to the roots that formed you. These are dishes that carry the flavor of childhood, the rigor of classical training, the boldness of reinvention and the tenderness of maturity. These are formulas that are not limited to ingredients and quantities as they contain gestures, silences, waiting times, and above all, intention. The legatee, chosen with discernment and trust, did not just receive a recipe book. He received a culinary testament, a map of values ​​and institutional responsibility. It will now be up to you to execute, preserve and reinterpret these creations with fidelity and courage, keeping the flame of authenticity alive without falling into the rigidity of repetition. In the Portuguese tradition, the transmission of recipes is an act of intimacy and respect. It's not just about teaching but about trust. Chef António understood this deeply. For this reason, the recipes he left were not disseminated en masse, nor transformed into a commercial product. They were given to those who knew how to understand his spirit, to those who shared his daily kitchen with him and to those who demonstrated technical ability and human sensitivity. These recipes include classic dishes and conventual desserts reinterpreted with local ingredients. But they also include new creations, designed for special occasions, themed menus and cultural tributes. These are dishes that never reached the public, but that can now be revealed with the care they deserve. Executing these recipes is not just reproducing flavors but embodying a philosophy. The legatee will have to maintain a balance between fidelity and evolution, technique and emotion, tradition and contemporaneity. You will have to respect the times, the gestures, the silences that Chef António taught. You will have to understand that each dish is also a message, a memory and an affirmation of identity. More than cooking, it will have to cure in a museological and emotional sense. Curate the legacy, protect it from trivialization and present it with dignity. You will have to train others, transmit the values ​​you received, ensure that the legacy does not disappear over time, but multiplies with meaning. This work is not just gastronomic but curatorial, educational and diplomatic. It is a way of affirming that cuisine is also culture, that the dish is also a document and that the flavor is also memory. The recipes left by Chef António are seeds. It is now up to the legatee and the institution involved to cultivate them with respect, water them with knowledge and make them flourish with creativity. Each time one of these recipes is served, it will be as if Chef António were present not as a shadow, but as a light. This legacy is a rare gift. And like any precious gift, it requires care, time and love. May it be honored with the same generosity with which it was conceived. May it be shared with the same elegance with which it was lived. May it be perpetuated with the same passion with which it was created. Because in the kitchen, as in life, what remains is not what is repeated, it is what is respected.

item.title: Sex and emotions
item.description: Sex can awaken a range of emotions. From positive to negative — including neutral — emotions often emerge in a haphazard way, without us being able to give them immediate meaning. There are those who even experience emotional combinations that place side by side emotions that at first glance would be opposites: pleasure and shame. These responses, however, are culturally shaped. Sex, deep down, is a microcosm of human emotional life, where body, culture and identity intersect. Attachment theory, often described as the theory of love, shows how the search for security, or its absence, shapes our emotional response in relationships with others. The body has hormonal mechanisms associated with pleasure, which make us feel safe, but also others that can perpetuate our sense of insecurity. The way emotional responses are created depends largely on context and our past experiences. Therefore, emotions often become a lens through which we look at the world. The psychology of emotions has crossed two important lineages to understand these mechanisms. One of them is medicine, where emotion results from physiological construction and regulation. The other comes from anthropology, which has explored how culture shapes our emotional responses. For example, intercultural studies have shown that in more individualistic societies, where anger is a form of expression of breaking relationships with others – in an attempt to impose limits – the physiological response is stronger than in collectivist societies. In societies where the group configuration has a more determining weight on the sense of self, anger is just an indicator that there is disharmony in the group relationship, and the physiological response and inflammation levels are lower. Anger is not perceived as a radical break from the collective, and therefore the experience of anger is, in some way, more sustained. This cultural dimension becomes even more evident when we analyze the way in which various gender expressions construct their emotional worlds. Although popular culture tells us that there are differences between 'men' and 'women', the truth is that there is much more variability within each group than between them, which makes it difficult to justify a clear distinction. This division is culturally fueled and manifests itself in everyday gestures. Studies show that when women arrive at an emergency room with palpitations, they are more quickly diagnosed with anxiety than with a heart attack. The same does not happen with men, from whom a lesser emotional manifestation is expected, and therefore symptoms such as palpitations are rarely confused with anxiety. Thus, it becomes almost expected for women to express excessive emotions and for men to repress them — which distorts our notion of what is ‘normal’ or ‘deviant’. It is worth bringing here an essential distinction in the theory of emotions: there are primary emotions, which are more immediate and more faithful to our internal states, and secondary emotions, which are in some way a complexification of the first, fed by beliefs, narratives and cultures. If at a certain moment I feel angry, and if my life experience has taught me that anger is an inappropriate emotion, other emotions quickly take over, such as shame or guilt. All of this is relevant to better understanding emotions during sex. In the reductive binarism of custom, generalist beliefs persist that impose performance pressure on men and feelings of guilt on women — dynamics that are also reflected in same-sex relationships. When we realize that the emotions that emerge do not correspond to what culture defines as 'normal', we begin to monitor and censor what we feel. Without a deep understanding of emotions, the body and the context in which they are inserted, we end up complicating our lives. For example, the emotions that follow sex vary as much as the experiences themselves. Some feel a peaceful well-being, a feeling of closeness and tenderness — the so-called afterglow. Others experience the opposite: a certain melancholy or emptiness known as post-sex dysphoria. These emotional states seem to depend less on the physical act and more on the meaning that each person attributes to it — connection, validation, curiosity or loneliness. Emotions are closely linked to the meanings we attribute to things. It is the deeper conversations about emotions that free us from the artificial limits that prevent full emotional honesty. Only by understanding these processes — which translate social contexts and cultural narratives into physiological and emotional responses that the body carries — can we better understand sex, its pleasures and its difficulties. And if we treat sex as a conversation between bodies and emotions — perhaps we can listen to ourselves, and others, with more presence and empathy.

item.title: The Pat Sin Leng Fire
item.description:
On the 10th, it became known through the Hong Kong media that an eight-year-old child had made three calls to the police claiming that there was a fire in Pat Sin Leng, Tai Po, and that 25 teachers and students were trapped on the mountain. After the alert, the police, together with the Agriculture and Fisheries department and the Fire Department, arrived at the scene and verified that there was no fire. The boy was later located, admitted that he had lied and received a verbal warning. Although this incident is nothing more than a trivial matter, unlikely to arouse public concern, it does not fail to awaken painful memories. The phrase “there is a fire in Pat Sin Leng” evokes memories of the accident that occurred 30 years ago. On February 10, 1996, four teachers from Fung Yiu King Memorial School in Hong Kong accompanied a group of Year 7 and 8 students on a hike in Pat Sin Leng. It is suspected that the fire started because someone threw a burning cigarette into the bush. The fire spread across the mountain and the way down was blocked, forcing everyone to climb. Due to the difficulties of the terrain, they had to climb the “Maliu Cliff” rock to escape. Two teachers stayed behind to help the students climb the cliff. Thirty-two managed to return to the starting point to seek help. After helping most of the young people, the two teachers were unable to climb the cliff and died in the fire along with two students. In this incident, two teachers and three students died and thirteen were injured. Another hiker, who had helped rescue some of the fire victims, later self-imposed, possibly due to suffering from post-traumatic stress. In 1996, the Court ruled that the cause of the accident was “undoubtedly human”, but it was not clear whether it was due to a poorly extinguished cigarette or a fire that may have been lit as a joke. To honor the sacrifice of the two teachers, the Hong Kong Government had a pavilion erected in their memory in Pat Sin Leng, called “Spring Breeze Pavilion,” which means “good teachers” in Chinese.” Inside the pavilion, bilingual inscriptions in Chinese and English recount the entire incident. Two Buddhist pine trees were planted in front of the pavilion, in honor of the two teachers. A plaque commemorating the Spring Breeze Pavilion is placed at the entrance to Fung Yiu King Memorial School. Memorial services are held annually to share the events with students. The Fung Yiu King Memorial School has partnered with the Chinese University of Hong Kong to create a scholarship in memory of the two teachers named after them. The boy's lie undoubtedly rekindled painful memories. These memories should disappear over time instead of remaining in people's memories. Let's hope the lies end here and never resurface. May the painful memories be carried away by the wind. The spirit of the two teachers who sacrificed themselves for others lives on in Hong Kong society and is celebrated by all. We need to ask: why do we celebrate altruism? Is it because we only have one life, so when someone sacrifices themselves for others they deserve respect? The answer is not that simple. We only have one life and after death there is nothing more. The reason for celebrating self-sacrifice for the benefit of others is a way of celebrating the fact that someone capable of this act is completely devoid of selfishness, someone who only wants the good of others. This is a pure manifestation of love for humanity. If those who have been saved can continue to pass on this love, selfishness will decrease and genuine friendship will increase. With this kind of unifying love, there will naturally be no hostility, because love brings together. In this sense, love can promote a more peaceful and harmonious society and everyone will be happy. In today's complex society, human hearts are unpredictable. Even if we want to bring our love to others, it is not always accepted. This is undoubtedly a harsh reality. The students who were injured in Pat Sin Leng, and who faced many trials, must certainly have left those bad times behind, strived to live their lives and start a new chapter, but at the same time they must have remembered the two teachers who saved them. Their ability to sacrifice on behalf of students is not only worthy of imitation, but it is a lesson that must be learned and passed on. Only love can unite us all in a selfless way. It has been thirty years since the Pat Sin Leng fire, but time will not fade the memory of the sincere and selfless love that these two teachers gave to their students. Through today's news, let us once again silently pay tribute to them. May they live happily in the Afterlife, and may the love they had for their students continue to be transmitted forever.
Legal Consultant of the Association for the Promotion of Jazz in Macau Associate Professor at the Faculty of Management Sciences of the Macau Polytechnic University Email: cbchan@mpu.edu.mo

item.title: Spinumviva “kills” Montenegro
item.description: Luís Montenegro's family business Spinumviva has been making waves for many months. All the media has announced the most diverse suspicions about the activity and management of the current Prime Minister's family company. The family business was made up of Montenegro, his wife and two children. It has already been designated as a consultancy, real estate, resource management company and who knows what else. What came to light is that hundreds of thousands of euros were entered into the family company's account in contracts with economic groups and other companies, such as Solverde, owner of casinos and potential competitor in the new competition for awarding licenses for casinos. Montenegro started to be talked about because he had a house in ruins, in Espinho, which he transformed into a luxury property with the city's privileged contractor, where the mayor president was a close friend of Montenegro. Meanwhile, as Montenegro had not declared all of its assets to the Transparency Entity, totaling 55 properties, the Public Prosecutor's Office (MP) decided to initiate a preventive investigation (?) into the activity of the company in question, particularly the construction of the aforementioned house in Espinho and the origin of the funds for the acquisition of two apartments in Lisbon carried out by Montenegro. The Public Prosecutor's Office understood that the case can only be clarified in criminal proceedings that will have to be formally opened in the Supreme Court of Justice. The MP even made it known that the case should be passed on to a judicial investigation as it included suspicions against Montenegro that included improper receipt of benefits and money laundering. Remember, for much less, a Government fell just because the Attorney General's Office decided to insert a paragraph in a statement that stated that Prime Minister António Costa could be under investigation. However, the cases and cases of Spinumviva, the family company from Montenegro, have come to the fore for a variety of reasons. One of them, because Montenegro has provided the Transparency Entity and the MP with documentation requested from the “mouthwashes”… One of the questions raised by several television commentators relates to the denial of the current Attorney General of the Republic, Amadeu Guerra, appointed by Prime Minister Luís Montenegro, that he has not yet given the green light to investigators to move from a preventive investigation (something that is neither flesh nor fish) to a judicial inquiry, similar to what has happened with many others who were quickly contacted by different politicians and presidents of football clubs. Amadeu Guerra's Prosecutor's Office issued a statement, which read that “the preventive investigation into the Spinumviva case is ongoing and that the MP is still awaiting documentation” requested from Montenegro. And what reason does Montenegro have for not sending the documentation quickly? But last week, in the middle of the electoral campaign for the local elections, another “bomb” went off regarding Montenegro. The media continued to report that Montenegro had gone on vacation to Brazil and that all expenses had been paid by Spinumviva. Wow, another “little thing” that led opposition political leaders to speak out, from André Ventura (Chega) to José Luís Carneiro (PS). And what did Montenegro respond? That everything was “a little shameful”. Whose shame? The media that has the obligation to inform? Little shame on the MP for breaking court secrecy and dropping the news on CNN Portugal, because investigators were fed up with Montenegro's attitude and Amadeu Guerra's orders? Or little shame in going on vacation with everything paid for by a family company that claims to be just a consultancy company? PAN spokesperson, Inês Sousa Real, for example, went public to regret yet another suspicion regarding the Prime Minister, stressing that “we do not want to believe that the times of Justice are the times of electoral campaigns, we do not align with this narrative like the one in which the Prime Minister has been justifying what has been the scrutiny throughout this process”. Much further went Paulo Raimundo, leader of the PCP, who clearly called for the prime minister's resignation. Raimundo even seemed to know something confidential about the government hosts, because, in fact, the replacement of Montenegro by Leitão Amaro or Paulo Rangel had already been considered. For our part, we do not believe that Montenegro will resign. Only if a criminal case is opened on all suspicions and the conclusion of the investigation will it be decided to give Montenegro a trial in court. Today, my reading friends already know the results of the local elections and if the AD allied with the Liberal Initiative (IL) won the elections, then, in that case, I am sure that Montenegro will not resign even if the Santa Justa elevator falls… The Prime Minister cannot escape the popular judgment that is beginning to sentence him as a case similar to that of José Sócrates. The people have already concluded that Montenegro did not comply with the laws, that something happened in the context of corruption and money laundering, that the Prime Minister only promises an increase in pensions and salaries during the election campaign, that he brought forward the delivery of the State Budget so that in the middle of the election campaign he could announce that the minimum wage would be close to one thousand euros. Of all the turns Montenegro takes in billiards, there is one thing that no longer saves him. His family company Spinumviva has already “killed” him politically in the eyes of the people.

item.title: FRC | Debate on criminal issues in the PLP takes place today
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) presents today, starting at 6:30 pm, a debate on “Paradigmatic Penal Issues in Portuguese-Speaking Countries”, which includes four thematic lectures. This is an initiative that is part of the “Cycle of Reflections at Dusk”, moderated by Leonor Esteves, from Universidade Lusíada do Porto. Today, the sessions “Nullum crimen sine lege and article 7 (Custom) of the Constitution of the Republic of Angola” are taking place, led by professor Luzia Bebiana de Almeida Sebastião, from the Faculty of Law of the Agostinho Neto University, Angola; and the conversation “Criminal Law and Democracy: the recent experience of the Brazilian case” by professor Fernando Andrade Fernandes, from the Department of Public Law of the Faculty of Human and Social Sciences of the Universidade Estadual Paulista, UNESP, Brazil. Another session is entitled “The material legitimacy of the crime of association in Mozambican law” by legal advisor and professor Elysa Vieira, from the Constitutional Council and Eduardo Mondlane University, Mozambique; and also the “Inviolability of communications and seizure of electronic mail” by professor Maria João Antunes, from the Faculty of Law of the University of Coimbra. The presence in the territory of this group of guest speakers is part of the 15th International Law Conference, this year dedicated to “Macau Legal Reforms in the Global Context: Studies on the Penal Code and the Macau Criminal Procedure Code”, organized by the Legal Studies Center of the Faculty of Law of the University of Macau, which takes place today and tomorrow and has the support of the FRC.

item.title: Literature | “In Memory” is the new book from publisher Mandarina
item.description: The new editorial project of Mandarina, a publisher dedicated to children's literature, will be launched on October 25th. “In Memória” is part of the collection “Pequenos Exploradores de Macau” which addresses the universes of Macau’s memory and heritage through the writing of Catarina Mesquita Publisher Mandarina has teamed up with a series of partners, including the International Institute of Macau (IIM), to launch a new book for children that explores the worlds of heritage and the importance of preserving it and remembering a territory in permanent mutation. “Na Memória”, written by Catarina Mesquita and with illustrations by Fernando Chan, brings back the adventures of the characters Júlia and Pou, she talking to her father; him talking to his grandmother. To HM, Catarina Mesquita reveals the reasons for choosing the theme of memory for this new book, the third in the “Pequenos Exploradores de Macau” collection, which includes the titles “Na Rua” and “Em Casa”. "The dynamics are the same [in relation to the previous books]: it is a book with two stories and two characters, but the ending is common. I decided on memory not only because of the importance it has in our lives, but to convey to children the idea that everything we experience is very important and is part of our construction, especially children who live in Macau, as they see things evolving that should stay within them." The co-edition with the IIM is due to the fact that it is celebrating 25 years since the inscription of the historic center of Macau as a heritage site classified by UNESCO. "Memory is part of this heritage, of its preservation. As our books have always highlighted places, festivities and situations in Macau, we thought we could continue the collection and associate ourselves with this important landmark." Three books, six stories “In Memória” is a bilingual book, in Portuguese and traditional Chinese, also having an interactive part with stickers, with words in both languages ​​and in Patuá, a Macanese dialect that is practically on the verge of extinction. "We decided to include the patuá because of this connection with memory and heritage. So the book has two pages of stickers in which readers observe the scenery and in which more importance is given to the illustration", explained Catarina Mesquita. "The way I portrayed memory is always associated with the children's vision and the curious questions they ask. We have Júlia interacting with her father and Pou with his grandmother about the experiences they have over the course of a year, which is the time period of the story. They ask questions and there are things that register in their heads." The author of the book describes a part of the story in which Júlia climbs the Macau Tower with her father and he explains to her the future of Macau, built with the new city of Hengqin. Júlia is an eight-year-old girl who is seeing a new city being born, while “Pou's grandmother is 80 years old and has been in Macau for a long time, so she has memories of a Macau that her grandson doesn't know”. “There is this transition between the past, present and future to make children think a little, that things change and to make them realize that there are things that, in their lives in Macau, really change, like this case of looking around and seeing a mega-city growing”, said the founder of Mandarina. Having existed for almost six years in the small publishing market of Macau, Catarina Mesquita talks about what still needs to be done so that greater emphasis is placed on children's literature. "We know the market we have, which is not very significant. We cannot reach all the children in Macau and we feel that there is a lack of support that is not just financial. Although there are [financial, project support] funds, much greater support is needed in terms of values. In recent years the Macau Government has promoted children's literature and reading, but there is no situation in which publishers work together to develop children's literature in Macau", he laments. Catarina Mesquita understands that this type of literature is still seen as not having “great priority, especially that which is made for leisure and not that which is given in schools”. "There is little investment in this reading for pleasure and there needs to be greater investment, in addition to taking a serious look at this type of children's literature, as it is essential for the future. It is necessary to give children this basis, so that they look at the book as a companion object", he concluded. The presentation of the book will take place on the 25th as part of the “Exhibition of Illustrated Books in Chinese and Portuguese”, at the Carmo Auditorium, in Taipa, starting at 6:30 pm.

item.title: Influencers | “CreatorWeek Macao 2025” starts next week
item.description:
It’s called “CreatorWeek Macao 2025” and it will be a week dedicated to exploring the universe of digital influencers and their connection to the territory. Under the theme “Macau – young, international and innovative city”, there is a whole program of activities taking place between the 24th and 28th of October with 250 groups of people involved in the creation of digital content
Next week, Macau will host, for the first time, an event entirely dedicated to digital influencers, who use social media to create content, often sponsored. “CreatorWeek Macao 2025” takes place from the 24th to the 28th of October and is promoted by the Tourism Services Department (DST) and the company Branded. According to a statement from DST, during the five days, the aim is to bring together “international and Greater China content creators” in the territory, as well as “social media leaders and celebrities”. This event aims to “raise the image of Macau as a famous tourist city on the Internet”, in order to “strengthen the expansion of the younger visitor market and boost the development of the tourism economy”. Helena de Senna Fernandes, director of DST, said that with “CreatorWeek Macao 2025” it is possible to “show, at an international level, the diversity and uniqueness of Macau’s attraction”. This influencer week is intended to serve as a “platform for international creators to learn about the Chinese market and boost dialogue between both sides”, bringing together around 250 international and Greater China guest groups, including 180 content creation teams, 50 speakers and 20 action units. The organization considers this initiative “one of the biggest current events in Asia for content creatives”. In total, there will be six thematic activities that aim to “boost in-depth exchanges between Chinese and Western creative industries, reinforce Macau's role as a high-quality outdoors platform and create immersive experiences throughout the city”. Music and fun On the 27th and 28th of October, conferences will take place at the Grand Lisboa Palace, between 9am and 6pm, with “local content creators and 50 international social media leaders”, such as those responsible for YouTube for Greater China, among others. These two days of conferences focus on “the fusion of Chinese and Western cultures and trends in communication platforms, panorama and future of the creative economy”. Live performances with 20 local and international bands and musicians are also expected this influencer week. The musical part takes place between the 25th and 26th of October, from 4pm to 10pm, at Broadway Food Street, in Galaxy Macau. Artists such as Lola Amour, Oliver Cronin, Mikey Bustos AKA Antscanada and SCAMPER are included. The event also promotes platform follower meetings with 40 content creators, namely freestyle dance artist Merrick Hanna, short video specialist Austin Sprinz or Netflix actor Ian Boggs, who will interact closely, take photos and share behind-the-scenes stories with fans. This week, there is also space for well-being activities and health workshops with content creators, with four sessions of yoga, dance, fitness and meditation. The first edition of “Creator Week” was held in Singapore last year.

item.title: “Halftone 25” | Photography exhibition opens today at FRC
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) presents today, starting at 6:30 pm, the Collective Photographic Exhibition “Halftone’ 25”, which brings together the annual works of 23 amateur and professional artists, members of Halftone — Macau Photographic Association, curated by Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro and Francisco Ricarte. The collective exhibition reveals a total of 23 works, ranging from documentary photography to artistic expression, including landscape, human, studio, conceptual, “street photography”, color or black-and-white photography. As in previous years, images were selected, some already known and others new, by authors such as André Carvalhosa, António Mil-Homens, António Sotero, António Bessa Almeida, Cássia Schutt, Catarina Cortesão Terra, Carmen Serejo, Cristiana Figueiredo, David Lopo, Elói Scarva, Francisco Ricarte, Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro, Inela Kovacevic, Joana Freitas, João Miguel Barros, João M. Rato, João Palla Martins, Jorge Veiga Alves, José das Neves, José Sales Marques, Kuok Hou Tang, Nélson Silva and Nuno Calçada Bastos. Halftone is a non-profit cultural association created in 2021, based in Macau, which aims to promote contemporary photography in all its aspects. Founded in an inclusive and comprehensive way, it is open to all those interested in photography as an artistic or documentary expression, regardless of their experience or practice. In addition to boosting the photographic work of its members, Halftone also aims to organize exhibitions, publish a magazine, books and monographs, organize debates and develop pedagogical and educational projects. This exhibition will be on display until October 25th, 2025.

item.title: Tourism | Andy Wu calls for greater disclosure of intangible heritage
item.description: Andy Wu, president of the Macau Tourism Industry Association, argues that intangible cultural heritage should be more widely publicized to tourists, at a time when the Cultural Institute has just announced 12 new classifications, namely the making of cream puffs and traditional almond cookies, traditional Chinese wedding cakes and the making of jook-sing dough. According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the association leader understands that cultural tourism offers can include intangible cultural heritage, providing extraordinary experiences to tourists, namely the holding of custard tart and almond biscuit workshops, among others. This type of event would be organized between the sector, education linked to tourism and personalities from society, so that visitors would have more information about the production process. Andy Wu hopes that the Government will provide more support as he understands that these initiatives can help to overcome the lack of spaces for tourists to have these types of experiences. Few stores still make traditional Chinese wedding cakes.

item.title: Taiwan | Residents seduced people into scams
item.description:
This Monday, six residents were arrested on suspicion of being linked to a criminal group in Taiwan associated with fraud, and who had recruited nine residents to extort money from victims. The investigation began in September last year, and the Judicial Police is still investigating the amounts involved
This Monday, the Judiciary Police arrested six Macau residents allegedly involved with a Taiwanese criminal group associated with fraud. According to the Ou Mun newspaper, the case began when the Judiciary Police (PJ) began an investigation after receiving requests for help from family members of nine missing Macau residents. Authorities later realized that these nine residents had been detained by Taiwan police and sentenced to prison terms of three to eight months for committing the crime of fraud. The role of these residents was to receive and deliver the extorted money to fraud victims, with four of these residents later returning to Macau after serving their sentence. It is estimated that the nine residents received thousands to tens of thousands of renminbi in payment for these roles. The Macau PJ then realized that the nine residents tried in Taiwan had been recruited by the six arrested on Monday, with promises of high salaries to carry out illegal activities in the former Formosa. Amounts to be calculated The PJ also realized that two of the six detainees are the main perpetrators of the criminal group in Taiwan, having received illegal payments of 1 to 3 percent for each amount of fraud extorted by the nine residents detained in Taiwan. However, the PJ said it needed to investigate the specific amounts received by these two main perpetrators of the crime, as well as the illegal remuneration received by the other suspects. The case was forwarded to the Public Prosecutor's Office for further investigation, as there are suspicions of the crime of criminal association.

item.title: Economy | Stability forecast in the fourth quarter
item.description: The Macau Economic Association has just released the latest Prosperity Index, which forecasts a stable economy until December. According to a statement from the association, despite considering the performances of the gaming and tourism sectors during Golden Week to be excellent, there are economic areas that still perform weaker, such as consumption, credit and confidence in local investments. For this reason, the association assigned, on a scale of 0 to 10, 6.2 points, 6 points and 6.1 points, respectively, for the months of October, November and December with regard to the economic situation, which means a level of stability. Furthermore, the association highlighted that data related to tourism and gaming in the third quarter were strong, predicting positive growth in Gross Domestic Product of around 7 percent in the third quarter. Foreign Exchange Reserves | Monthly increase of 1.6% In September, the Macao SAR's foreign exchange reserves increased by 1.6 percent to 239.2 billion patacas, compared to the adjusted amounts in August. The data was released yesterday by the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM), through a press release. In August, foreign exchange reserves reached 235.4 billion patacas. The effective exchange rate of the pataca, weighted by its trade shares, was 100.8 in September 2025, which represented a drop of 0.06 points in monthly terms and an annual reduction of 1.60 points. In view of this variation, AMCM reported that globally “the pataca fell against the currencies of Macau’s main trading partners”.

item.title: Habitação | Loans sink 34 percent
item.description: In August, the value of new housing loans approved by Macau banks registered an annual reduction of 34.8 percent, according to data released yesterday by the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM). In August this year, new housing loans represented 820.82 million patacas, whereas in August 2024 they had reached 1.26 billion patacas. When the comparison is made between August of this year and the previous month, July, the reduction was 22.2 percent, compared to the value of 1.05 billion reported by AMCM. Of the 820.82 million patacas approved in new loans, residents were responsible for 806.05 million, a reduction of 22.5 percent compared to the previous month. In relation to commercial loans for real estate activities, in August the value was 1.14 billion patacas, an annual increase, given that in August 2024 the value had been 954.23 million patacas. At the end of August 2025, the unpaid debt ratio on housing loans was 3.8 percent, an increase of 0.1 percentage points compared to July. In relation to August 2024, non-compliance decreased by 0.5 percentage points, as at that time it was 4.3 percent. The unpaid debt ratio of commercial loans for real estate activities reached 5.5 percent, an increase of 0.1 percentage points compared to July. In annual terms, non-compliance grew by 1.6 percentage points.

item.title: 929 Challenge | Startups from PALOP and Timor rise 73 percent
item.description: The Sino-Lusophone 929 Challenge competition, held in Macau, attracted 170 startups from Portuguese-speaking African Countries (PALOP) and Timor-Leste, 73 percent more than in 2024, one of the organizers told Lusa yesterday. Marco Duarte Rizzolio, co-founder of the 929 Challenge, chose the increased participation of less developed Portuguese-speaking countries as the highlight of the fifth edition of the 929 Challenge. The professor at the City University of Macau justified the rise with the competition's new partners: “we signed strategic agreements with Cabo Verde Digital and Eduardo Mondlane University [Mozambique]”. Since the end of the last edition, in November 2024, Rizzolio has already been to Angola twice to promote the 929 Challenge, while the other co-founder, José Alves, visited São Tomé and Príncipe and Timor-Leste. “They are very small countries, with a very small population and a very poorly developed ecosystem, but we are even able to have projects there”, highlighted the organizer, thanks to “a particularity of developing countries”. In countries with a relatively low average age, “also due to the lack of jobs, young people are full of energy, they are very open to developing businesses”, explained Rizzolio. A new prize The fifth edition of the 929 Challenge in Macau includes for the first time the ‘Future Builders’ award, for the best startup in the PALOP and Timor-Leste. The only time that a team from PALOP and Timor-Leste reached the finalists was in the first edition, launched in 2021, in the middle of the covid-19 pandemic, then only aimed at university students. A project by the Lusófona University of Guinea-Bissau to install solar panels in the Gabu region, in the east of the country, came in second place. Rizzolio also highlighted that, for the first time, startups from Portuguese-speaking countries – including Portugal and Brazil – are in the majority in the 929 Challenge, representing around 65 percent of the 402 participants. “We had many more projects coming here from [mainland] China”, said the organizer. The 929 Challenge “has already acquired a certain notoriety”, defended Rizzolio, namely through the promotion carried out at the SIM Conference, in May, in Porto, and at the Web Summit, in June, in Rio de Janeiro. The online bootcamp of the 929 Challenge began on Monday, having attracted more than 400 teams and startups, an increase of more than 25 percent compared to 2024. The last edition of the competition had recorded a maximum, with more than 1,600 participants in more than 320 teams. The final is scheduled for November 30th. The competition is co-organized by Forum Macau and several Macau institutions, including all local universities.

item.title: Prostitution | Police cooperation action arrests 18 people
item.description: A joint police action between Macau, Hong Kong and Guangdong led to the dismantling of a prostitute control group, with 18 people arrested. According to the Chinese channel Radio Macau, eight of the people detained are residents of Macau. In this joint operation, 58 prostitutes and 44 clients were intercepted. The case dates back to May, when the Judiciary Police (PJ) began the investigation, realizing that there were several prostitutes looking for clients through the same website with alleged links to a criminal group with members from the province of Guangdong, Macau and Hong Kong. This Monday, the joint police operation began, with arrests of suspects in several cities in China and in the two special administrative regions. The PJ believes that this group started the prostitute business through the website in January this year, advertising for more than 2,500 prostitutes, which brought a profit of 750 thousand renminbi. The PJ also described that each prostitute had to pay the group 300 renminbi to advertise and thus attract customers.

item.title: JP Morgan | Golden Week with results below expectations
item.description:
The passage of two typhoons, the proximity of the Mooncake Festival and the Formula 1 Grand Prix in Singapore are indicated as factors that negatively affected the gaming industry
The game's revenue fell short of expectations during Golden Week and the situation is unlikely to improve until November. The scenario was outlined by the investment bank JP Morgan, in the most recent report signed by analysts DS Kim, Selina Li and Lindsey Qian. According to the content, released by the Macau News Agency, revenues at the beginning of October “were not that golden”, with a reduction of five percent compared to the same period last year. According to analysts, the impacts of typhoon Ragasa, which forced casinos to close for a few hours, and also typhoon Matmo, which despite not closing gaming venues, led to transport being seriously affected, contributed to the decline in revenue. And also the fact that the Lunar Festival was celebrated close to Golden Week. As a date for family gatherings, the festival may have contributed to players spending less time at casino tables. However, Macau will also have suffered from regional competition and the organization of the Formula 1 Grand Prix in Singapore. Analysts believe that the event that took place between the 3rd and 5th of October contributed to keeping some of the biggest gamblers away from the territory. In view of these phenomena, JP Morgan revised gaming revenue estimates downwards, pointing to annual growth in October of 3 to 6 percent. The previous estimate predicted growth of 11 to 13 percent, in what was expected to be the best Golden Week since the pandemic. Positive sign Despite reducing estimates, analysts left a sign of confidence in the Macau gaming market: "We are not throwing in the towel. We see these factors as speed bumps and not as roadblocks, so despite reducing our estimates we believe in the market's value", it was pointed out. Given this context, analysts believe that the appreciation of casino shares should show strong variations in the coming weeks, until the industry returns to growth of at least 10 percent. JP Morgan believes that this growth should happen from December and during the first quarter of next year. In September, the gaming sector raised 18.3 billion patacas, 6 percent more than in September last year. In terms of accumulated gross revenue, the first nine months of 2025 recorded an increase of 7.1 percent compared to the same period last year, reaching 181.3 billion patacas. Macau closed 2024 with total revenue of 226.8 billion patacas, 23.9 percent more than in the previous year.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. He says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Men should refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish because of it, tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the land will be destroyed. pride of countries. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were limited, or if it simply lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each one. to be, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters are eight years old – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the place of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, in a different way, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: China | Airlines dispute US proposal to ban flights over Russia
item.description: China's main state-owned airlines contested a United States proposal to ban flights that cross Russian airspace on routes between the two countries, citing an impact on passengers and a competitive imbalance. Air China, China Eastern and China Southern are among six Chinese carriers that have filed complaints with the US Department of Transportation against the order, proposed last week, which seeks to ban flights over Russia by Chinese carriers. In its response, China Eastern claimed that the measure “harms the public interest” and “creates inconvenience for travelers” from China and the US, stressing that increased flight times would translate into higher costs and more expensive fares. China Southern warned that the ban would negatively affect thousands of passengers, while Air China estimated that at least 4,400 travelers would be affected if the restriction came into force during the Thanksgiving (November 27) and Christmas season. Russian airspace was closed to North American airlines and most European carriers in 2022 following the imposition of Western sanctions over Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Chinese flights, however, continue to have access, giving them, according to Washington, an unfair advantage over their US competitors. Chinese diplomacy spokesman Guo Jiakun had already reacted last week, considering that the proposal represents a “punishment” for passengers from all over the world. According to David Yu, an aviation sector expert at New York University in Shanghai, the impossibility of flying over Russia has increased the duration of some US-China routes by two to three hours, putting pressure on the operational costs and profitability of North American companies. “Historically, the China-US route has been highly profitable for both sides,” Yu said. “If Chinese carriers can fly over Russia, their costs are lower,” he noted.

item.title: Apple | Tim Cook will reinforce presence and cooperation with China
item.description: Apple's executive president, Tim Cook, yesterday assured the Chinese Minister of Industry and Information Technology that the North American technology company will reinforce investment and deepen cooperation with China, aiming for “mutually beneficial” development.
